u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Web of Science', u'sequence': 2}], u'issns': [u'0385-2342'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'This essay revisits a debate that took place in the social sciences over the "sacred-cow controversy" for the purpose of ecological musing. The debate was stimulated largely by Marvin Harris, whose cultural materialist position reduced the symbolism of the cow in Hinduism to a set of irrational beliefs. His alternative was to see the cow\'s sacredness in terms of a calculus of calories. Needless to say, his work led to criticism from both anthropologists and humanists. In the first part of the paper, I trace the history of the controversy, then move on to consider the cow herself from a Hindu point of view. Finally, I conclude with some theoretical remarks about the need for scholars of religion to be sensitive to both texts and contexts by blurring the theoretical boundaries between the fields of religion and anthropology.', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'This essay revisits a debate that took place in the social sciences over the "sacred-cow controversy" for the purpose of ecological musing. The debate was stimulated largely by Marvin Harris, whose cultural materialist position reduced the symbolism of the cow in Hinduism to a set of irrational beliefs. His alternative was to see the cow\'s sacredness in terms of a calculus of calories. Needless to say, his work led to criticism from both anthropologists and humanists. In the first part of the paper, I trace the history of the controversy, then move on to consider the cow herself from a Hindu point of view. Finally, I conclude with some theoretical remarks about the need for scholars of religion to be sensitive to both texts and contexts by blurring the theoretical boundaries between the fields of religion and anthropology.', u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}, {u'abstract': u'\xa0 Korom revisits a debate that took place in the social sciences over the "sacred-cow controversy" for the purpose of ecological musing. The debate was stimulated by Marvin Harris, whose cultural materialistic position reduced the symbolism of the cow in Hinduism to a set of irrational beliefs.', u'attribution': u'Platinum: Social Sciences'}]}

u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://apps.webofknowledge.com/WOS_GeneralSearch_input.do?last_prod=WOS&product=WOS&highlighted_tab=WOS&search_mode=GeneralSearch', u'dbid': u'EGQ', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Web of Science', u'sequence': 2}], u'issns': [u'0094-0496'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'\xa0 Possession religions have frequently been treated as women\'s means to redress their subordination. Like many other religions so discussed, the Oyo-Yoruba worship of Sango and Yemoja endures in a predominantly Muslim region. The following discussion will illustrate that such religions, though highly gendered in their symbolism and personnel, need not redress the interests of women or of the deprived alone. For the weak and the strong, they may dramatize a rival construction of collective life. In order to grasp how they do so, we must understand (1) the history of Islam and such possession religions in the particular context and, therefore, (2) the way they constitute each other in that context. As they serve and structure material rivalries in the world, they take on each others\' signs and criteria of power. The gendered religious pluralism of the Oyo-Yoruba illustrates a gestalt common across "the Muslim world" and bears implications for the study of possession religions practiced in conjunction with other "world religions" as well. Reprinted by permission of the publisher.', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u"Possession religions have frequently been treated as women's means to redress their subordination. Like many other religions so discussed, the Oyo-Yorubi worship of Sango and Yemoja endures in a predominantly Muslim region. The following discussion will illustrate that such religions, though highly gendered in their symbolism and personnel, need not redress the interests of women or of the deprived alone. For the weak and the strong, they may dramatize a rival construction of collective life. In order to grasp how they do so, we must understand (1) the history of Islam and such possession religions in the particular context and, therefore, (2) the way they constitute each other in that context. As they serve and structure material rivalries in the world, they take on each others' signs and criteria of power. The gendered religious pluralism of the Oyo-Yoruba illustrates a gestalt common across ''the Muslim world'' and bears implications for the study of possession religions practiced in conjunction with other ''world religions'' as well.", u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}]}

of popular musical performance and the instruments featured in them and shows how their age-related imagery, commentary and interaction express changing intergenerational relationships.', u'attribution': u'Platinum: Social Sciences'}, {u'abstract': u'Youth cannot be understood without examining elderhood, and age more generally. Among the Tuareg, Islamic religious rituals and liturgical music fend to be identified with the "aged" (those with children of marriageable age), and these are symbolically opposed to secular popular musical performances classified as "anti-Islamic," which are identified with "youth." These images comment upon long-standing concerns with marriage, courtship, sexuality, and descent, but they are also increasingly being translated into concerns of cultural autonomy, as local youths struggle for cultural survival in conflict between Tuareg and the central state. I analyze three types of popular musical performance and the instruments featured in them, and show how their age-related imagery, commentary, and interaction express changing intergenerational relationships. These concerns, however do not fall into a binary of "old" and "new," or align with any one age group; rather, they suggest shifting associations of agentive power and questioning of "tradition" by youth and aged in diverse contents. These data on age symbolism in Tuareg popular musical performances suggest more dynamic nuanced formulations of "traditional," "modern," and "global" in anthropological theory.', u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}, {u'abstract': u'Youth cannot be understood without examining elderhood, and age more generally. Among the Tuareg, Islamic religious rituals and liturgical music tend to be identified with the "aged" (those with children of marriageable age), and these are symbolically opposed to secular popular musical performances classified as "anti-Islamic," which are identified with "youth." These images comment upon long-standing concerns with marriage, courtship, sexuality, and descent, but they are also increasingly being translated into concerns of cultural autonomy, as local youths struggle for cultural survival in conflict between Tuareg and the central state. I analyze three types of popular musical performance and the instruments featured in them, and show how their age-related imagery, commentary, and interaction express changing intergenerational relationships. These concerns, however, do not fall into a binary of "old" and "new," or align with any one age group; rather, they suggest shifting associations of agentive power and questioning of "tradition" by youth and aged in diverse contexts. These data on age symbolism in Tuareg popular musical performances suggest more dynamic, nuanced formulations of "traditional," "modern," and "global" in anthropological theory.', u'attribution': u''}]}

u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Web of Science', u'sequence': 2}, {u'url': u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://www.scopus.com', u'dbid': u'BKL', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Scopus', u'sequence': 3}], u'issns': [u'0002-7294'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u"This article brings together theories of local modernity and of linguistic ideology to analyze the way the Urapmin of Papua New Guinea have encountered modern linguistic ideology through their Christianization. Against the prevailing anthropological focus on the indigenization of modernity, this article argues the importance of attending to cases in which people grasp the content of modernity on its own terms. Studying this kind of local modernity allows us to model an important kind of contemporary cultural change and discover neglected aspects of modernity as refracted through the experiences of people new to it. Here, an analysis of the Urapmin encounter with modern linguistic ideology reveals that ideology's rootedness in a model that ties meaning to intention and truthfulness and favors the speaker over the listener in the construction of meaning. It is suggested that an awareness of the biases of this ideology can open up new topics in linguistic anthropology. [ modernity, linguistic ideology, religion, Christianity, Melanesia ]", u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u"\xa0 This article brings together theories of local modernity and of linguistic ideology to analyze the way the Urapmin of Papua New Guinea have encountered modern linguistic ideology through their Christianization. Studying this kind of local modernity allows us to model an important kind of contemporary cultural change and discover neglected aspects of modernity as refracted through the experiences of people new to it. Here, an analysis of the Urapmin encounter with modern linguistic ideology reveals that ideology's rootedness in a model that ties meaning to intention and truthfulness and favors the speaker over the listener in the construction of meaning. It is suggested that an awareness of the biases of this ideology can open up new topics in linguistic anthropology. transactions in human tissue touch on fundamental ideas of the body, society, and the nature of giving. These issues have generally been discussed using Euro-American terms of reference. Drawing on fieldwork carried out in Sri Lanka, this article describes the ways in which a distinctively Therav\u0101da Buddhist notion of giving and charity has been linked to the development of strategies to encourage the donation of human tissue. Eye and blood donation are used as illustrations of the linkages that have been forged between religious duty, other-wordly aspirations, and nationalist sentiment in the development of national donation services. The key question which is then addressed is how these distinctive beliefs and values inform attempts to frame donations of sperm and ova which are now beginning to take place in Sri Lanka. In religious and cultural terms the candidacy of sperm and ova as gifts appears to be evaluated very differently. Explaining these differences opens up the possibility of a more thoroughgoing anthropological critique of bioethics and the manner of its diffusion both within and beyond the Euro-American context. / Les pr\xe9occupations \xe9thiques suscit\xe9es par les transactions de tissus humains sont ancr\xe9es dans les conceptions fondamentales relatives au corps, \xe0 la soci\xe9t\xe9 et \xe0 la nature du don. Ces questions sont g\xe9n\xe9ralement abord\xe9es dans le cadre du syst\xe8me de r\xe9f\xe9rences euro-am\xe9ricain. \xc0 partir de travaux sur le terrain au Sri Lanka, l'auteur d\xe9crit la mani\xe8re dont une conception du don et de la charit\xe9 typique du bouddhisme Therav\u0101da a \xe9t\xe9 exploit\xe9e dans l'\xe9laboration de campagnes encourageant les dons de tissus humains. Les dons d'yeux et de sang illustrent les relations \xe9tablies entre obligations religieuses, aspirations \xe0 l'autre monde et sentiment nationaliste pour d\xe9velopper les r\xe9seaux nationaux de dons d'organes. Le caract\xe8re \xab offrable \xbb des spermatozo\xefdes et des ovules est appr\xe9ci\xe9 tr\xe8s diff\xe9remment en termes religieux et culturels. u'BKL', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Scopus', u'sequence': 3}], u'issns': [u'0002-7294'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u"The concept of resistance has become one of anthropology's dominant theoretical preoccupations-so influential, in fact, that it threatens to overshadow other aspects of social life, to the detriment of our understanding of cultural complexity and creativity. Through a brief examination of two ethnographic cases from radically different social worlds, this essay assesses the perils of cultural accounts centered on resistance in particular and on ''the problem of power'' in general.", u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}, {u'abstract': u'The concept of resistance has become one of anthropology\'s dominant theoretical preoccupations - so influential, in fact, that it threatens to overshadow other aspects of social life, to the detriment of our understanding of cultural complexity and creativity. Through a brief examination of two ethnographic cases from radically different social worlds, this essay assesses the perils of cultural accounts centered on resistance in particular and on "the problem of power" in general.', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'Brown discusses the task of human anthropology. He examines why resistance and hegemony have come to monopolize the anthropological imagination.', u'attribution': u'Platinum: Social Sciences'}, {u'abstract': u'The emergence & status of resistance in modern anthropological inquiry are examined. Resistance has become a dominant theme in anthropological inquiry & has overwhelmed study of other aspects of social life, eg, cooperation & reciprocity. In part, the dominance of resistance stems from the contentiousness of the modern age, but it also has disciplinary origins -- the diminished importance of revolutionary ideas such as Marxism & adherence to vaguer standards of truth. Two brief ethnographic cases illustrate the uses & limitations of the resistance concept: (1) the struggle of the Ashaninka Indians of eastern Peru, & (2) the New Age practice of channeling in the US. 20 References. Adapted from the source document.', u'attribution': u'Sociological Abstracts'}]}

between culture, power, and politics in contemporary Cuba through the lens of hip-hop. In particular, I look at the interactions between Cuban rappers, the Cuban socialist state, and diverse transnational networks in a moment of economic crisis, increasing racial disparities, and Cuba's changing global position. The essay explores how the Cuban state has harnessed the energy of the growing hip-hop movement as a way of bolstering its popularity; I highlight forms of appropriation and collaboration between transnational cultural forms and the nation-state that have generally been absent from accounts of cultural globalization. But I also suggest that Cuban rappers' participation in transnational networks allows these rappers some autonomy to continue promoting messages of racial egalitarianism and to develop alternative strategies in a moment of declining options for black youth.", u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u"This essay analyzes the relationships between culture, power, & politics in contemporary Cuba through the lens of hip-hop. In particular, I look at the interactions between Cuban rappers, the Cuban socialist state, and diverse transnational networks in a moment of economic crisis, increasing racial disparities, and Cuba's changing global position. The essay explores how the Cuban state has harnessed the energy of the growing hip-hop movement as a way of bolstering its popularity; I highlight forms of appropriation and collaboration between transnational cultural forms and the nation-state that have generally been absent from accounts of cultural globalization. Bibliography of the Social Sciences (IBSS)', u'sequence': 1}, {u'url': u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://www.scopus.com', u'dbid': u'BKL', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Scopus', u'sequence': 2}], u'issns': [u'0094-0496'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'\xa0 In this article, I explore political consciousness and its relation to language, action, and power relations among schoolchildren and their parents in a small town in southern Turkey. More specifically, I draw on Wittgenstein\'s concept of language games to examine the ambiguous and indeterminate links between political discourse and educational practices, especially how these links are refracted in everyday life. Thus, I show that the term democracy, as used in the school system, has become a linguistic "scaffold" on which townspeople can arrange the political and social self-images they use to narrate their own life courses and life strategies. This sociolinguistic analysis of a political signifier, which draws out the relation among officially proscribed canons of representation, performances of hierarchy, and different understandings of polity and society across generations, lays groundwork for new approaches to the ethnography of the state.', u'attribution': u'Platinum: Social Sciences'}, {u'abstract': u'In this article, I explore political consciousness and its relation to language, action, and power relations among schoolchildren and their parents in a small town in southern Turkey. More specifically, I draw on Wittgenstein\'s concept of language games to examine the ambiguous and indeterminate links between political discourse and educational practices, especially how these links are refracted in everyday life. Thus, I show that the term democracy, as used in the school system, has become a linguistic "scaffold" on which townspeople can arrange the political and social self-images they use to narrate their own life courses and life strategies. This sociolinguistic analysis of a political signifier, which draws out the relation among officially proscribed canons of representation, performances of hierarchy, and different understandings of polity and society across generations, lays groundwork for new approaches to the ethnography of the state.', u'attribution': u''}]}

discussed: on the one hand, it is the voice of the alienated, frustrated and rebellious black youth who recognise their vulnerability and marginality in post-industrial America; on the other, rap is the packaging and marketing of social discontent. This duality made rap an explosive issue in the 1992 US presidential elections and beyond.', u'attribution': u'British Humanities Index (BHI)'}, {u'abstract': u'Black popular culture is still vibrant with revolutionary potential and continues its critique of authority and hatred of racism. However in its expression through film and music it has become increasingly nationalistic, money-oriented and sexist.', u'attribution': u'Applied Social Sciences Index and Abstracts (ASSIA)'}]}

Rather than a residue of a premodern culture in modern politics, terrorism is best understood as a modern construction.', u'attribution': u'Platinum: Social Sciences'}, {u'abstract': u'The link between Islam and terrorism became a central media concern following September 11, resulting in new rounds of "culture talk." This talk has turned religious experience into apolitical category, differentiating "good Muslims" from "bad Muslims," rather than terrorists from civilians. The implication is undisguised: Whether in Afghanistan, Palestine, or Pakistan, Islam must be quarantined and the devil must be exorcized from it by a civil war between good Muslims and bad Muslims. This article suggests that we lift the quarantine and turn the cultural theory of politics on its head. Beyond the simple but radical suggestion that if there are good Muslims and bad Muslims, there must also be good Westerners and bad Westerners, I question the very tendency to read Islamist politics as an effect of Islamic civilization-whether good or bad-and Western power as an effect of Western civilization. Both those politics and that power are born of an encounter, and neither can be understood outside of the history of that encounter. Cultural explanations of political outcomes tend to avoid history and issues. Thinking of individuals from "traditional" cultures in authentic and original terms, culture talk dehistoricizes the construction of political identities. This article places the terror of September 11 in a historical and political context. Rather than a residue of a premodern culture in modern politics, terrorism is best understood as a modern construction. Even when it harnesses one or another aspect of tradition and culture, the result is a modern ensemble at the service of a modern project.', u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}, {u'abstract': u'The link between Islam and terrorism became a central media concern following September 11, resulting in new rounds of "culture talk. This talk has turned religious experience into a political category, differentiating \'good Muslims" from "bad Muslims, rather than terrorists from civilians. The implication is undisguised: Whether in Afghanistan, Palestine, or Pakistan, Islam must be quarantined and the devil must be exorcized from it by a civil war between good Muslims and bad Muslims. This article suggests that we lift the quarantine and turn the cultural theory of politics on its head. Beyond the simple but radical suggestion that if there are good Muslims and bad Muslims, there must also be good Westerners and bad Westerners, I question the very tendency to read Islamist politics as an effect of Islamic civilization\u2014whether good or bad\u2014and Western power as an effect of Western civilization. Both those politics and that power are born of an encounter, and neither can be understood outside of the history of that encounter. Cultural explanations of political outcomes tend to avoid history and issues. Thinking of individuals from "traditional" cultures in authentic and original terms, culture talk dehistoricizes the construction of political identities. This article places the terror of September 11 in a historical and political context. Rather than a residue of a premodern culture in modern politics, terrorism is best understood as a modern construction. Even when it harnesses one or another aspect of tradition and culture, the result is a modern ensemble at the service of a modern project. [Keywords: Muslims, culture talk, Islamist politics, political identities, terrorism]', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'Mamdani places the terror of Sept 11, 2001 in a historical and political context. Rather than a residue of a premodern culture in modern politics, terrorism is best understood as a modern construction.', u'attribution': u'Sociological Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u'The link between Islam and terrorism became a central media concern following September 11, resulting in new rounds of "culture talk." This talk has turned religious experience into a political category, differentiating "good Muslims" from "bad Muslims," rather than terrorists from civilians. The implication is undisguised: Whether in Afghanistan, Palestine, or Pakistan, Islam must be quarantined and the devil must be exorcized from it by a civil war between good Muslims and bad Muslims. This article suggests that we lift the quarantine and turn the cultural theory of politics on its head. Beyond the simple but radical suggestion that if there are good Muslims and bad Muslims, there must also be good Westerners and bad Westerners, I question the very tendency to read Islamist politics as an effect of Islamic civilization--whether good or bad--and Western power as an effect of Western civilization. Both those politics and that power are born of an encounter, and neither can be understood outside of the history of that encounter. Cultural explanations of political outcomes tend to avoid history and issues. Thinking of individuals from "traditional" cultures in authentic and original terms, culture talk dehistoricizes the construction of political identities. This article places the terror of September 11 in a historical and political context. Rather than a residue of a premodern culture in modern politics, terrorism is best understood as a modern construction. u'BKL', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Scopus', u'sequence': 3}], u'issns': [u'0731-1214'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'Bonnie Mitchell and Joe Feagin (1995) build on the theory of oppositional culture, arguing that African Americans, American Indians, and Mexican Americans draw on their own cultural resources to resist oppression under internal colonialism. In this paper, rap music is identified as an important African American popular cultural form that also emerges as a form of oppositional culture. A brief analysis of the lyrics of political and gangsta rappers of the late 1980s and early 1990s, provides key themes of distrust, anger, resistance, and critique of a perceived racist and discriminatory society. Rap music is discussed as music with a message of resistance, empowerment, and social critique, and as a herald of the Los Angeles riots of 1992. /// [Spanish] Joe Feagin y Bonnie Mitchell (1995) desarrollaron sobre la teor\xeda de la cultura de opposici\xf3n, el argumento que los Afro Americanos, los Indios Americanos, y los Mexico Americanos obtuvieron dentro de a sus propios recursos culturales la forma de resistir la opresi\xf3n bajo colonialismo interno. En este trabajo, la m\xfasica Rap se identifica como una forma popular importante Afro Americana que tambi\xe9n emerge como una forma de cultura de oposici\xf3n. Un an\xe1lisis breve de la l\xedrica sobre pol\xedtica y gangsters del final de las d\xe9cadas de 1980 y el inicio de 1990, proporciona t\xe9rminos clave de desconfianza, enojo, resistencia, y cr\xedtica de una sociedad percibida como racista y discriminatoria. La m\xfasica Rap est\xe1 considerada como m\xfasica con un mensage de resistencia, facultativo, y de cr\xedtica social, y como un heraldo del los motines de Los Angeles de 1992. /// [Chinese] (Unicode for Chinese abstract). /// [Japanese] (Unicode for Japanese abstract).', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'Bonnie Mitchell and Joe Feagin (1995) build on the theory of oppositional culture, arguing that African Americans, American Indians, and Mexican Americans draw on their own cultural resources to resist oppression under internal colonialism. In this paper, rap music is identified as all important African American popular cultural from that also emerges as a form of oppositional culture. A brief analysis of the lyrics of political and gangsta rappers of the late 1980s and early 1990s, provides key themes of distrust, anger, resistance, and critique of a perceived racist and discriminatory society. Rap music is discussed as music with a message of resistance, empowerment, and social critique, and as a herald of the Los Angeles riots of 1992.', u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}, {u'abstract': u'Bonnie L. Mitchell & Joe R. Feagin (1995) build on the theory of oppositional culture, arguing that non-European groups (African & Mexican Americans & American Indians) draw on their own cultural resources to resist oppression under internal colonialism. Rap music is identified as an important African American popular cultural form that also emerges as a form of oppositional culture. A brief analysis of the lyrics of political & "gangsta" rappers of the late 1980s & early 1990s provides key themes of distrust, anger, resistance, & critique of a perceived racist & discriminatory society. Rap music\'s messages are seen as a herald of the 1992 Los Angeles (CA) riots. 98 References. Adapted from the source document.', u'attribution': u'Sociological Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u'\xa0 Rap music is an African American popular cultural form that is also a form of oppositional culture. Rap music is discussed as music with a message of resistance, empowerment, social critique and a warning of the Los Angeles riots of 1992.', u'attribution': u'Curriculum Essentials'}, {u'abstract': u'Bonnie Mitchell and Joe Feagin (1995) build on the theory of oppositional culture, arguing that African Americans, American Indians, and Mexican Americans draw on their own cultural resources to resist oppression under internal colonialism. In this paper, rap music is identified as an important African American popular cultural form that also emerges as a form of oppositional culture. A brief analysis of the lyrics of political and gangsta rappers of the late 1980s and early 1990s, provides key themes of distrust, anger, resistance, and critique of a perceived racist and discriminatory society. Rap music is discussed as music with a message of resistance, empowerment, and social critique, and as a herald of the Los Angeles riots of 1992.', u'attribution': u''}]}

u'BKL', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Scopus', u'sequence': 3}], u'issns': [u'0094-0496', u'1548-1425'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'In this ethnography of politics, the theory of the sublime is used to clarify the aesthetics of power among the Mende of Sierra Leone. A key formal dimension of this aesthetics is the dialectic of extraordinary visible effects caused by powerful hidden means, which is analyzed through the cultural analogy of dance and politics. This dialectic is also shown to link the aesthetics of the sublime with the politics of charisma as expressing similar logics of expressive power. Aesthetics is treated as an ethnographic heuristic for understanding political power and agency. The Mende political sublime raises broader questions for social theory about the relationship between aesthetics and agency as modeled by the opposition in aesthetic theory between beauty and the sublime. It also addresses the implications of this aesthetic opposition for the typology of agency found in the periodization of premodern, modern, and postmodern social conditions. [the sublime versus beauty, aesthetics of power, charisma, West African political culture, premodern versus postmodern agency]', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'In this ethnography of politics, the theory of the sublime is used to clarify the aesthetics of power among the Mends of Sierra Leone. This dialectic is also shown to link the aesthetics of the sublime with the politics of charisma as expressing similar logics of expressive power. Aesthetics is treated as an ehtnographic heuristic for understanding political power and agency. The Mende political sublime raises broader questions for social theory about the relationship between aesthetics and agency as modeled by the opposition in aesthetic theory between beauty and the sublime. It also addresses the implications of this aesthetic opposition for the typology of agency found in the periodization of premodern, modern, and postmodern social conditions.', u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}, {u'abstract': u'In this ethnography of politics, the theory of the sublime is used to clarify the aesthetics of power among the Mende of Sierra Leone. A key formal dimension of this aesthetics is the dialectic of extraordinary visible effects caused by powerful hidden means, which is analyzed through the cultural analogy of dance & politics. This dialectic is also shown to link the aesthetics of the sublime with the politics of charisma as expressing similar logics of expressive power. Aesthetics is treated as an ethnographic heuristic for understanding political power & agency. The Mende political sublime raises broader questions for social theory about the relationship between aesthetics & agency as modeled by the opposition in aesthetic theory between beauty & the sublime. It also addresses the implications of this aesthetic opposition for the typology of agency found in the periodization of premodern, modern, & postmodern social conditions. 114 References. Adapted from the source document.', u'attribution': u'Sociological Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u"\xa0 In aesthetic theory, the concept of the sublime provides a tool for developing the idea of power as wondrous and filled with awe, and offers a heuristic for understanding the logic of power by examining power's aesthetics.", u'attribution': u'Platinum: Social Sciences'}]}

the study of national character began in the US from WWII to the beginning of the Cold War. Research projects undertaken by anthropologists during WWII, particularly in relation to the postwar reconstruction of Japan, are highlighted. The history of anthropological thought is briefly chronicled & the emergence of theories of social engineering discussed. The issue of whether national character exists at all is considered. 48 References. W. Mills', u'attribution': u'Sociological Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u'Neiburg and Goldman analyze certain dimensions of a chapter in the history of anthropology, which unfolded in the US in the frame of the school of culture and personality in the period between the beginning WWII and the Cold War.', u'attribution': u'Platinum: Social Sciences'}, {u'abstract': u'Analyzes dimensions in the history of anthropology which unfolded in the U.S. in the frame of the school of culture and personality in the period between the beginning of World War 2 and the start of the Cold War. Considers that contrary to current representations of studies of national character, the examination of the conditions under which these studies were formulated and their theoretical and methodological proposals, can contribute to important debates in contemporary anthropology. (Quotes from original text)', u'attribution': u'Applied Social Sciences Index and Abstracts (ASSIA)'}]}

examine a Brazilian indigenous people\'s self-conscious use of the ideas of "culture" and "Indian ethnicity." Whereas analysts usually discuss indigenous use of these concepts in the context of high-profile national or transnational intercultural events, I Look at how retrospective accounts of participation in such events are woven into Local political discourse. I focus on how two Amazonian Leaders represent their participation in past events of cultural display as a means of mounting very different arguments about their eligibility for positions of authority in their community. I argue that Local frames of reference, for example, those relating to the culturally appropriate conduct of politics, must be considered in assessing the significance and meaning of cultural performances, even when the staging of indigenous culture is performed principally for a nonlocal audience.', u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}, {u'abstract': u'\xa0 In this article, I examine a Brazilian indigenous people\'s self-conscious use of the ideas of "culture" and "Indian ethnicity." Whereas analysts usually discuss indigenous use of these concepts in the context of high-profile national or transnational intercultural events, I look at how retrospective accounts of participation in such events are woven into local political discourse. I focus on how two Amazonian leaders represent their participation in past events of cultural display as a means of mounting very different arguments about their eligibility for positions of authority in their community. I argue that local frames of reference, for example, those relating to the culturally appropriate conduct of politics, must be considered in assessing the significance and meaning of cultural performances, even when the staging of indigenous culture is performed principally for a nonlocal audience. I focus on how two Amazonian leaders represent their participation in past events of cultural display as a means of mounting very different arguments about their eligibility for positions of authority in their community. I focus on how two Amazonian leaders represent their participation in past events of cultural display as a means of mounting very different arguments about their eligibility for positions of authority in their community. I argue that local frames of reference, for example, those relating to the culturally appropriate conduct of politics, must be considered in assessing the significance and meaning of cultural performances, even when the staging of indigenous culture is performed principally for a nonlocal audience. u'BKL', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Scopus', u'sequence': 3}], u'issns': [u'0094-0496'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'In this article, I examine the Gaucho Traditionalist Movement, which, with an active participation of two million people, claims to be the largest popular culture movement of the Western World. Based on the cult of the Gaucho in a specific cattle ranching area of Rio Grande do Sul (Brazil\'s southernmost state), the Gaucho Traditionalist Movement was created by nonacademic intellectuals, generally from the urban middle class. The movement eventually spread to more than two thousand "\'Centers for Gaucho Traditions" in all areas of the state, other parts of Brazil, and abroad. I analyze how and why Traditionalism made this three-stage distancing from its original point of reference, becoming a translocal and even transnational phenomenon. I discuss the role of intellectuals\' nostalgia for rural life in creating this form of popular culture. I show that traditionalist intellectuals have operated as intermediaries between knowledge produced in academia and popular culture movements, actively creating a popular culture that is frequently but mistakenly seen as being the product of the masses.', u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}, {u'abstract': u'In this article, I examine the Ga\xfacho Traditionalist Movement, which, with an active participation of two million people, claims to be the largest popular culture movement of the Western World. Based on the cult of the Ga\xfacho in a specific cattle ranching area of Rio Grande do Sul (Brazil\'s southernmost state), the Ga\xfacho Traditionalist Movement was created by nonacademic intellectuals, generally from the urban middle class. The movement eventually spread to more than two thousand "Centers for Ga\xfacho Traditions" in all areas of the state, other parts of Brazil, and abroad. I analyze how and why Traditionalism made this three-stage distancing from its original point of reference, becoming a translocal and even transnational phenomenon. I discuss the role of intellectuals\' nostalgia for rural life in creating this form of popular culture. I show that traditionalist intellectuals have operated as intermediaries between knowledge produced in academia and popular culture movements, actively creating a popular culture that is frequently but mistakenly seen as being the product of the masses. [tradition, popular culture, national and regional identity, transnational movements, intellectuals, Brazil, Ga\xfacho]', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'\xa0 Oliven examines the Gaucho Traditionalist Movement, which, with an active participation of two million people, claims to be the largest popular culture movement of the Western World. Based on the cult of the Gaucho in a specific cattle ranching area of Rio Grande do Sul, the Gaucho Traditionalist Movement was created by nonacademic intellectuals, generally from the urban middle class.', u'attribution': u'Platinum: Social Sciences'}]}

Tonga-speakers of Gwembe Valley, Zambia is often the father. Witchcraft fears have become more salient as worsening economic conditions have led to general malaise and the loosening of restraints on public accusation.', u'attribution': u'Gold: History'}, {u'abstract': u"In the 1990s the feared witch among Tonga-speakers of Gwembe Valley, Zambia, is often the father, whose adult children accuse him of using witchcraft to gain power over the child's life force to use in his enterprises. Suspicions of the father arise from changing family dynamics associated with restricted economic opportunities and a changing agricultural system involving cash cropping where family labour is of vital importance. Witchcraft fears, as elsewhere in Zambia, have become more salient as worsening economic conditions have led to general malaise and the loosening of restraints on public accusation. Feeling victimised and vulnerable in a world where transport minimises distance has led to witches being endowed with the power to operate without regard to distance. Nevertheless witchfinding deflects hostility from national political figures to elders in the neighbourhood, especially fathers, who are continuous sources of immediate frustration and are also vulnerable to local action./Dans les ann\xe9es 90, la sorci\xe8re que l'on craint au sein de la population de langue Tonga de la vall\xe9e du Gwembe, en Zambie, est souvent le p\xe8re, que les enfants adultes accusent d'user de la sorcellerie pour manipuler leur force vitale \xe0 son profit. Les suspicions \xe0 l'\xe9gard du p\xe8re r\xe9sultent d'un changement de la dynamique familiale, \xe0 laquelle s'ajoutent des perspectives \xe9conomiques limit\xe9es et une agriculture en pleine \xe9volution impliquant des cultures commerciales pour lesquelles la main-d'\u0153uvre familiale est d'une importance vitale. Comme dans le reste de la Zambie, la peur de la sorcellerie est devenue plus frappante au fur et \xe0 mesure que la situation \xe9conomique se d\xe9gradait, cr\xe9ant un malaise g\xe9n\xe9ral et un laisser-aller quant aux accusations publiques. Le sentiment d'\xeatre pers\xe9cut\xe9 et vuln\xe9rable dans un monde o\xf9 les transports minimisent les distances fait doter les sorci\xe8res du pouvoir d'exercer leurs pouvoirs \xe0 des distances illimit\xe9es. N\xe9anmoins, la chasse aux sorci\xe8res d\xe9tourne l'hostilit\xe9 des personnalit\xe9s politiques nationales pour la porter sur les anciens des communaut\xe9s, notamment les p\xe8res, que sont une source permanente de frustration imm\xe9diate et sont vuln\xe9rables \xe0 l'action locale.", u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u"In the 1990s the feared witch among Tonga-speakers of Gwembe Valley, Zambia, is often the father, whose adult children accuse him of using witchcraft to gain power over the child's life force to use in his enterprises. Suspicions of the father arise from changing family dynamics associated with restricted economic opportunities and a changing agricultural system involving cash cropping where family labour is of vital importance. Witchcraft fears, as elsewhere in Zambia, have become more salient as worsening economic conditions have led to general malaise and the loosening of restraints on public accusation. Feeling victimised and vulnerable in a world where transport minimises distance has led to witches being endowed with the power to operate without regard to distance. Nevertheless witchfinding deflects hostility from national political figures to elders in the neighbourhood, especially fathers, who are continuous sources of immediate frustration and are also vulnerable to local action.", u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}, {u'abstract': u"In the 1990s the feared witch among Tonga-speakers of Gwembe Valley, Zambia, is often the father, whose adult children accuse him of using witchcraft to gain power over the child's life force to use in his enterprises. Suspicions of the father arise from changing family dynamics associated with restricted economic opportunities and a changing agricultural system involving cash cropping where family labour is of vital importance. Witchcraft fears, as elsewhere in Zambia, have become more salient as worsening economic conditions have led to general malaise and the loosening of restraints on public accusation. Feeling victimised and vulnerable in a world where transport minimises distance has led to witches being endowed with the power to operate without regard to distance. Nevertheless witchfmding deflects hostility from national political figures to elders in the neighbourhood, especially fathers, who are continuous sources of immediate frustration and are also vulnerable to local action. Dans les ann\xe9\xe9es 90, la sorci\xe8\xe8re que l'on craint au sein de la population de langue Tonga de la vall\xe9\xe9e du Gwembe, en Zambie, est souvent le p\xe8\xe8re, que les enfants adultes accusent d'user de la sorcellerie pour manipuler leur force vitale \xe0\xe0 son profit. Les suspicions \xe0\xe0 l'\xe9\xe9gard du p\xe8\xe8re r\xe9\xe9sultent d'un changement de la dynamique familiale, \xe0\xe0 laquelle s'ajoutent des perspectives \xe9\xe9conomiques limit\xe9\xe9es et une agriculture en pleine \xe9\xe9volution impliquant des cultures commerciales pour lesquelles la main-d'\u0153\u0153uvre familiale est d'une importance vitale. Comme dans le reste de la Zambie, la peur de la sorcellerie est devenue plus frappante au fur et \xe0\xe0 mesure que la situation \xe9\xe9conomique se d\xe9\xe9gradait, cr\xe9\xe9ant un malaise g\xe9\xe9n\xe9\xe9ral et un laisser-aller quant aux accusations publiques. Le sentiment d'\xea\xeatre pers\xe9\xe9cut\xe9\xe9 et vuln\xe9\xe9rable dans un monde o\xf9\xf9 les transports minimisent les distances fait doter les sorci\xe8\xe8res du pouvoir d'exercer leurs pouvoirs \xe0\xe0 des distances illimit\xe9\xe9es. N\xe9\xe9anmoins, la chasse aux sorci\xe8\xe8res d\xe9\xe9toume l'hostilit\xe9\xe9 des personnalit\xe9\xe9s politiques nationales pour la porter sur les anciens des communaut\xe9\xe9s, notamment les p\xe8\xe8res, que sont une source permanente de frustration imm\xe9\xe9diate et sont vuln\xe9\xe9rables \xe0\xe0 l'action locale.", u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'Discusses the Tonga-speakers of the Gwembe Valley in Zambia and their belief that witchcraft steers their lives. Cites case histories of those accused of being witches and notes their common social situations. Indicates that an accusation of witchcraft often comes after the supposed witch has amassed a certain amount of wealth and after those in close relation to him suffer infirmity or death. Focuses on the shift the Tonga-speakers have made since the 1980s to accuse their own fathers of being witches due to economic and social influences. Describes the repercussions that occur after an accusation is made.', u'attribution': u''}]}

u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Web of Science', u'sequence': 2}], u'issns': [u'0094-0496'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'The anthropology of postcolonialism has tended to neglect or homogenize the varied expressions of cultural and national identity of British settler descendants. Against the backdrop of research with white settler descendants who farm large Crown pastoral lease properties in the South Island high country of New Zealand, this article examines evidence they presented before the Waitangi Tribunal about their attachment to land as a politicized expression of belonging, of one set of Pakeha voices. It analyzes how high country runholders speak about and symbolically construct belonging and suggests that the high country landscape is a central metaphor in the conceptual systems of its inhabitants, providing them with a way of thinking about their cultural distinctiveness within the arena of contestations in the meanings of cultural identities defined by the Waitangi Tribunal. [postcolonial settler identity, New Zealand high country, land claims, sheep station life, anthropology of place]', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'The anthropology of postcolonialism has tended to neglect or homogenize the varied expressions of cultural and national identity of British settler descendants. Against the backdrop of research with white settler descendants who farm large Crown pastoral lease properties in the South Island high country of New Zealand, this article examines evidence they presented before the Waitangi Tribunal about their attachment to land as a politicized expression of belonging, of one set of Pakeha voices. It analyzes how high country runholders speak about and symbolically construct belonging and suggests that the high country landscape is a central metaphor in the conceptual systems of its inhabitants, providing them with a way of thinking about their cultural distinctiveness within the arena of contestations in the meanings of cultural identities defined by the Waitangi Tribunal.', u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}, {u'abstract': u'\xa0 \\Evidence presented before the Waitangi Tribunal by white settler descendants who farm in the high country of New Zealand is analyzed in terms of how they speak about and construct belonging. u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Web of Science', u'sequence': 1}], u'issns': [u'0094-0496'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'This article concerns the conceptual relationships among individualism, social order, and moral hierarchy in the United States. Ethnographic research in a suburban town revealed preoccupations with the links among the avoidance of overt conflict, valorization of the local "way of life," and positive moral values. In searching for a wider cultural context of these local concerns, the article considers individualism as a conflict discourse that structures the social and moral meanings of disputes. Further, it considers the larger significance of a cultural conception of society that disparages the role of plaintiff. The theme throughout is the relationship between equality and hierarchy envisioned by those whose worldview is the subject of the article.', u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}, {u'abstract': u'\xa0 The conceptual relationships among individualism, social order and moral hierarchy in the US are examined. Ethnographic research in a suburban town revealed preoccupations with the links among the avoidance of overt conflict, valorization of the local "way of life" and positive moral values.', u'attribution': u'Platinum: Social Sciences'}, {u'abstract': u'This article concerns the conceptual relationships among individualism, social order, and moral hierarchy in the United States. Ethnographic research in a suburban town revealed preoccupations with the links among the avoidance of overt conflict, valorization of the local "way of life," and positive moral values. In searching for a wider cultural context of these local concerns, the article considers individualism as a conflict discourse that structures the social and moral meanings of disputes. Further, it considers the larger significance of a cultural conception of society that disparages the role of plaintiff. The theme throughout is the relationship between equality and hierarchy envisioned by those whose worldview is the subject of the article. [United States, individualism, egalitarianism, hierarchy, conflict, law]', u'attribution': u''}]}

This article argues that an escape from the nihilistic excesses of deconstructionism is possible if ethnicity is 'relocated' from the narrow space it inhabits in current theories (social, cultural or psychological) to the active interface between the mind, society and culture.", u'attribution': u'Platinum: Social Sciences'}, {u'abstract': u'Weakly theorized, lacking even an agree definition, ethnicity has joined the list of deconstructed concepts in anthropology. This article argues that an escape from the nihilistic excesses of deconstructionism is possible if ethnicity is "relocated" from the narrow space it inhabits in current theories (social, cultural, or psychological) to the active interface between the mind, society, & culture. Two bodies of case material (from urban Papua New Guinea & New Zealand) are presented here in an attempt to demonstrate that, first, ethnicity is the product of an empirically available activity, classifying people according to their origins, & second, a great deal of cultural & symbolic content accretes to these classifications. When ethnicity becomes subject to the elaborations of cultural or identity politics it often develops into a focus of symbolic contestation. The symbolic & ideological elaborations of ethnicity present analysts with phenomena analytically separate from ethnic classification itself. 45 References. u'name': u'Scopus', u'sequence': 2}], u'issns': [u'0304-4092'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'Arguing that "education in the orthodox sense in which it is pursued in Africa may not be the panacea that once was assumed," a call is made for a fundamental reevaluation of the role of education in solving the many social problems of sub-Saharan Africa. A comparative analysis of all the countries in the region demonstrates the problem of retrogression in education, supported by statistical data on declines in human development, school enrollment, & expenditures on education. It is argued that nothing less than a "cataclysmic" change in philosophy will reverse this situation; suggestions for a new philosophy of education, & implications for the design of curriculum, pedagogy, & policy, are outlined. Traditional (precolonial), missionary/colonial, & postindependence educational systems are compared, suggesting that present problems can be linked to programmatic & ideological legacy of the colonial system. The inextricable links between culture, education, & change must be acknowledged, & local education programs must move beyond the "education for development" focus that has guided previous efforts. 4 Tables, 1 Figure. K. Hyatt Stewart', u'attribution': u'Worldwide Political Science Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u'Arguing that "education in the orthodox sense in which it is pursued in Africa may not be the panacea that once was assumed," a call is made for a fundamental reevaluation of the role of education in solving the many social problems of sub-Saharan Africa. A comparative analysis of all the countries in the region demonstrates the problem of retrogression in education, supported by statistical data on declines in human development, school enrollment, & expenditures on education. construction of racial stratification configured the patterning of violence.', u'attribution': u'Platinum: Social Sciences'}, {u'abstract': u"Somalia was one of the first states to crumble in the post-cold war era. This article undresses the image of Somalia as the one true nation-state in Africa, arguing that the political economy of class and regional dynamics underscored the dissolution of the Somali nation-state and that the cultural construction of racial stratification configured the patterning of violence. Explaining Somalia's dissolution is a contribution to the anthropological project of theorizing the global disintegration of nation-states. u'BKL', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Scopus', u'sequence': 3}], u'issns': [u'0002-7294'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'The attacks of September 11, 2001, in the United States and the U.S.-led campaign in Afghanistan provoked fierce threats of violence in Indonesia, the world\'s largest majority-Muslim country, Western journalists portrayed these reactions as among the most destabilizing in the Muslim world. Less widely reported, however, was the intensification of a struggle between Muslim proponents of democracy and neofundamentalist conservatives, sparked by the same incidents. This article explores the varied reactions of Muslims to the violence of September 11 and its aftermath in light of this contest between rival Muslim groupings. It examines their competing visions of Islam and nation, as well as their supporting alliances in state and society. The example highlights the pluralism of Muslim politics and the special challenges of democratic transitions. Emphasizing the plurality and permeability of civilizations, the example also suggests that there is no "clash of civilizations" between Islam and the West but, rather, a more open process of globalization, localization, and exchange.', u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}, {u'abstract': u"The Sept 11, 2001 terrorist attacks in the US and the US-led campaign in Afghanistan provoked fierce threats of violence in Indonesia, the world's largest majority-Muslim country. Hefner explores the varied reaction of Muslims to the violence of Sept 11, 2001 and its aftermath in light of the views of rival Muslim groupings.", u'attribution': u'Platinum: Social Sciences'}, {u'abstract': u"The Sept 11, 2001 terrorist attacks in the US and the US-led campaign in Afghanistan provoked fierce threats of violence in Indonesia, the world's largest majority-Muslim country. Hefner explores the varied reaction of Muslims to the violence of Sept 11, 2001 and its aftermath in light of the views of rival Muslim groupings.", u'attribution': u'Sociological Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u'The attacks of September 11, 2001, in the United States and the U.S.\u2010led campaign in Afghanistan provoked fierce threats of violence in Indonesia, the world\'s largest majority\u2010Muslim country. Western journalists portrayed these reactions as among the most destabilizing in the Muslim world. Less widely reported, however, was the intensification of a struggle between Muslim proponents of democracy and neof undamentalist conservatives, sparked by the same incidents. This article explores the varied reactions of Muslims to the violence of September 11 and its aftermath in light of this contest between rival Muslim groupings. It examines their competing visions of Islam and nation, as well as their supporting alliances in state and society. The example highlights the pluralism of Muslim politics and the special challenges of democratic transitions. Emphasizing the plurality and permeability of civilizations, the example also suggests that there is no "clash of civilizations" between Islam and the West but, rather, a more open process of globalization, localization, and exchange. [Keywords: Islam, Indonesia, violence, democratization, civilization]', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'The attacks of September 11, 2001, in the United States and the U.S.-led campaign in Afghanistan provoked fierce threats of violence in Indonesia, the world\'s largest majority-Muslim country. Western journalists portrayed these reactions as among the most destabilizing in the Muslim world. Less widely reported, however, was the intensification of a struggle between Muslim proponents of democracy and neofundamentalist conservatives, sparked by the same incidents. This article explores the varied reactions of Muslims to the violence of September 11 and its aftermath in light of this contest between rival Muslim groupings. It examines their competing visions of Islam and nation, as well as their supporting alliances in state and society. The example highlights the pluralism of Muslim politics and the special challenges of democratic transitions. Emphasizing the plurality and permeability of civilizations, the example also suggests that there is no "clash of civilizations" between Islam and the West but, rather, a more open process of globalization, localization, and exchange.', u'attribution': u''}]}

u'BKL', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Scopus', u'sequence': 3}], u'issns': [u'0003-5491', u'1534-1518'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'This article considers rumors the backbone of what Michael Taussig calls "the nervous system." For the last three decades Haiti has been a thoroughly nervous, sometimes terrifying place, struggling in the grip of violence, fear, and despotic repression. The grapevine in Haiti is a dangerous and highly charged place where stories of violence and magic can paralyze people with fear and confusion, but it is also the place of a type of speaking that limits the ability of any institution or government to define social knowledge totally. Authoritarian forces depend upon word of mouth to help spread terror and fear. To accomplish this they must drive speaking out of open public debate and into the back alleys of rumors. But in passing rumors speakers create an alternative public sphere and maneuver to speak in oppositional voices. It is the task of a critical anthropology to interrogate these forms and to work out methods of explanation that are appropriate to such practices.', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'\xa0 The grapevine in Haiti is a dangerous and highly charged place where stories of violence and magic can paralyze people with fear and confusion, but it is also the place of a type of speaking that limits the ability of any institution or government to define social knowledge totally.', u'attribution': u'Platinum: Social Sciences'}, {u'abstract': u"Examines the role of rumors in Haitian politics after the 1991 coup d'etat. The grapevine in Haiti is a dangerous & highly charged place where stories of violence & magic can paralyze people with fear & confusion, but it is also the place of a type of speaking that limits the ability of any institution or government to fully define social knowledge. Authoritarian forces depend on word of mouth & rumors to help spread terror & fear. But, in passing rumors, speakers create an alternative public sphere & maneuver to speak in oppositional voices. It is the task of a critical anthropology to interrogate these forms & to work out methods of explanation that are appropriate to such practices. 33 References. Adapted from the source document.", u'attribution': u'Sociological Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u"This article considers rumors the backbone of what Michael Taussig calls ''the nervous system''. For the last three decades Haiti has been a thoroughly nervous, sometimes terrifying place, struggling in the grip of violence, fear, and despotic repression. The grapevine in Haiti is a dangerous and highly charged place where stories of violence and magic can paralyze people with fear and confusion, bur it is also the place of a type of speaking that limits the ability of any institution or government to define social knowledge totally. Authoritarian forces depend upon word of mouth to help spread terror and fear. To accomplish this they must drive speaking out of open public debate and into the back alleys of rumors. But in Passing rumors speakers create an alternative public sphere and maneuver to speak in oppositional voices. it is the task of a critical anthropology to interrogate these forms and to work out methods of explanation that are appropriate to such practices.", u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}]}

u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/wpsa/advanced?accountid=14434', u'dbid': u'7UB', u'source_types': [u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Worldwide Political u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Web of Science', u'sequence': 2}, {u'url': u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://www.scopus.com', u'dbid': u'BKL', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Scopus', u'sequence': 3}], u'issns': [u'0265-0525'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'For this collection entitled "After Socialism," we were asked to reflect upon such questions as what rectifications (if any) to present market capitalist systems might be desirable and whether there is any viable remnant in the socialist ideal that ought to be preserved. My basic answer to the latter is that the socialist principle of distribution "From each according to abilities, to each according to needs" remains a compelling moral ideal, superior to the resigned, complacent, or enthusiastic acceptance of economic inequality that is offered by defenders of conventional capitalism and by many versions of liberalism. And so, my answer to the former is that the rectifications to present market capitalist systems that would be desirable would be to reduce the deep injustices and social malformations of these systems as much as possible by moving their distributive outcomes in the direction of the socialist ideal. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]', u'attribution': u'ProQuest Religion'}, {u'abstract': u'It is argued that socialist principles of distribution remain a "compelling moral ideal" superior to the acceptance (whether by resignation, complacency, or endorsement) of the economic inequalities of conventional capitalism (& some forms of liberalism). However, the central planning & authoritarian politics characteristic of previous socialist systems in practice are not defensible. Ways that social ideals are fully compatible with a commitment to individual freedom are explored, challenging criticisms of the fairness of the requirement that individuals contribute to production according to their abilities & receive according to their needs. It is also argued that market capitalism has many variants with many different patterns of distribution & that there is room for improvement in distributive outcomes; the viability of the socialist ideal of distribution & its potential for the realization of egalitarian justice are considered. K. Hyatt Stewart', u'attribution': u'Sociological Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u'It is argued that socialist principles of distribution remain a "compelling moral ideal" superior to the acceptance (whether by resignation, complacency, or endorsement) of the economic inequalities of conventional capitalism (& some forms of liberalism). However, the central planning & authoritarian politics characteristic of previous socialist systems in practice are not defensible. Ways that social ideals are fully compatible with a commitment to individual freedom are explored, challenging criticisms of the fairness of the requirement that individuals contribute to production according to their abilities & receive according to their needs. It is also argued that market capitalism has many variants with many different patterns of distribution & that there is room for improvement in distributive outcomes; the viability of the socialist ideal of distribution & its potential for the realization of egalitarian justice are considered. K. Hyatt Stewart', u'attribution': u'Worldwide Political Science Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u'Offers an interpretation and defense of the socialist ideal of distribution and indicates its relevance to contemporary capitalist societies. Defends the fairness of the socialist ideal, including its requirement that people contribute to production according to their abilities. Considers objections to the socialist ideal that are raised in the name of freedom.', u'attribution': u'Applied Social Sciences Index and Abstracts (ASSIA)'}]}

u'name': u'Social Services Abstracts', u'sequence': 1}], u'issns': [u'0048-3915'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u"A person deserves something always in virtue of something true of him, a 'ground for deserving.' Some antimeritocratic arguments claim that no one deserves those grounds usually advanced as justifying differential SE rewards, & that therefore no one deserves special rewards. It is argued that the requirement that we deserve our grounds for deserving is invalid in cases of 'personal desert' generally & only valid in some cases. In particular it is false in cases of 'human desert.' The notion of human desert lies behind many egalitarian theories. In cases of human desert equal shares are assigned to people satisfying some minimal condition on deservingness, even if they are unequally deserving. A theory of just distributions based upon such a notion will differ markedly from Aristotelian theories that require a proportionality between relative shares & relative deservingness. AA.", u'attribution': u'Social Services Abstracts'}]}

138', u'thumbnail_small': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/sc.gif&issn=0264-3758&client=summon', u'fulltext_link': u'http://tufts.summon.serialssolutions.com/2.0.0/link/0/eLvHCXMwpV1LS8NAEB6KXgriW6wPyNGDsWs22SRQCtUaxINWtIKnsI_ssZU2Ffz37myybRRBxFPIsCzJPr9vd-YbABpcEP_bmpBiihpl0LIh0JdUCRJxRWKBet5pktowtsd79vRCs2Fy1QKXtLNSi1gev-E8sat3Y7p3q9ihlBJ7qRB1ucAzAlnismzAOvKx4GHl9UHsBahhHqGZW1FSq_38UNHXjWqFPpsY1m5C2RYsXCiP9cBe-qC4Dy8Xupw3PLSbUo__-MNt2KxRqzeohtkOtIrJLrRHLg3Cxx689kS_1thGYN_riv65Z2xDFOa1ObXeCzSirc4g5l75RHkGhnrj-dI01V42nVVF9mGc3Txf3_p12gZfGnIV-VrSUCMt1IYaiUCYXZgJJkKUAlMxDxhlBgVKlkoqCBM8UFqmUqcFkRKTn9MD2ODo3j8pbRigOgSPR1qSUImooEXISZEoFJZPIpS2kQEJO3DmOit_q2Q6ckdvsPlybD7rvxd14NR1Zu5acm4KU2bGYkziDvi2G36rJ78bjEbmefTH8sfQrqQf8BjnBNbK2aI4hXU7Rj4BUTjqZg', u'publisher': u'Blackwell Publishers Ltd', u'end_pages': [u'138'], u'page_counts': [u'16'], u'is_a_i': False, u'thumbnail_large': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=0264-3758&client=summon', u'start_pages': [u'123'], u'eissns': [u'1468-5930'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Publisher', u'Index Database', u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'16'], u'databases': [{u'url': u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/bhi/advanced?accountid=14434', u'dbid': u'C18', u'source_types': [u'Index Database'], u'name': u'British Humanities Index (BHI)', u'sequence': 1}], u'issns': [u'0264-3758'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u"To whom do we owe obligations of distributive justice? Political theorists like David Miller and Yael Tamir contend that members of nations owe special, enforceable obligations of distributive justice to fellow nationals. Offers a critique of the nationalists' account of distributive justice, and concludes that it is untenable. (Original abstract - amended)", u'attribution': u'British Humanities Index (BHI)'}, {u'abstract': u"To whom do we owe obligations of distributive justice? In the last decade a number of distinguished political theorists \u2014 such as David Miller and Yael Tamir \u2014 have defended a nationalist account of our distributive obligations. This paper examines their account of distributive justice. In particular, it analyses their contention (a) that individuals owe special obligations to fellow\u2010nationals, (b) that these obligations are obligations of distributive justice and (c) that these obligations are enforceable. Miller and Tamir's justifications, I argue, do not support these claims. Moreover, I argue, (a) and (c) should only be accepted in a greatly qualified form and (b) should be rejected altogether. The paper thus concludes that the nationalists' preferred account of distributive justice is untenable.", u'attribution': u''}]}

socio-political world, social work ethics needs to re-cast the moral identity of the social worker in terms of virtue ethics. We review virtue theory's Aristotelian foundations and criticisms of Kantian and utilitarian theory and show how they apply to social work. Subsequently we offer an account of a virtue-based social work that questions the validity of several models of practice currently fashionable. Virtue theory emphasizes the priority of the individual moral agent who has acquired virtues commensurate with the pursuit of a revisable conception of the good life\u2014the well-being of all in a defined community. The virtues are the acquired inner qualities of humans\u2014character\u2014the possession of which, if applied in due measure, will typically contribute to the realization of the good life or 'eudaimonia'. The role of the virtuous social worker is shown to be one that necessitates appropriate application of intellectual and practical virtues such as justice, reflection, perception, judgement, bravery, prudence, liberality and temperance. This 'self-flourishing' worker, in bringing together the capacity for theoretical and practical action makes possible a hermeneutic or interpretive praxis best appraised in dialogue with fellow-practitioners and clients. With a social work remit increasingly routinized by accountability, quality control and risk management there is an emphasis on regulation and duties. This has produced a culture of following approved or typical processes resulting in defensive forms of social work wholly uncongenial to the development of human qualities likely to promote social workers' engagement in critique and revision of what counts as best practice. In sum, our core proposition is that social work practice and education, to fit an unpredictable, non-linear world, should develop means by which professionals nurture the virtues. The virtues are the acquired inner qualities of humans -- character -- the possession of which, if applied in due measure, will typically contribute to the realization of the good life or "eudaimonia." The role of the virtuous social worker is shown to be one that necessitates appropriate application of intellectual & practical virtues such as justice, reflection, perception, judgement, bravery, prudence, liberality, & temperance. This "self-flourishing" worker, in bringing together the capacity for theoretical & practical action makes possible a hermeneutic or interpretive praxis best appraised in dialogue with fellow-practitioners & clients. With a social work remit increasingly routinized by accountability, quality control, & risk management there is an emphasis on regulation & duties. This has produced a culture of following approved or typical processes resulting in defensive forms of social work wholly uncongenial to the development of human qualities likely to promote social workers\' engagement in critique & revision of what counts as best practice. In sum, our core proposition is that social work practice & education, to fit an unpredictable, nonlinear world, should develop means by which professionals nurture the virtues. u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Web of Science', u'sequence': 2}, {u'url': u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://www.scopus.com', u'dbid': u'BKL', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Scopus', u'sequence': 3}], u'issns': [u'0265-0525'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'Considers whether differences in income and wealth should matter. Suggests that one should seize on moral intuition - in this case called sibling parity - and see how a battery of assumptions steers this intuition in the direction of an answer. Whatever gets filtered out by those assumptions inevitably makes a heavy contribution to counter-arguments aimed at circumventing the given answer. (Original abstract - amended)', u'attribution': u'Applied Social Sciences Index and Abstracts (ASSIA)'}, {u'abstract': u'Several assumptions underlying arguments in support of the contention that differences in income & wealth "matter" are explored, focusing on the notion of sibling parity. If it is assumed that wealth itself matters, primarily as a function of the well-being it provides, can it then be assumed that differences or inequalities in wealth matter? The idea of "permissible disparity" is considered & related to ideas about luck, natural adversity, & individual responsibility. It is suggested that sibling wealth parity should matter, but only ceteris paribus, conditional on its ability to deliver sibling parity in well-being. Additionally, sibling parity is argued to be constrained by personal responsibility; extensions to nonsibling parity are entertained. K. Hyatt Stewart', u'attribution': u'Worldwide Political Science Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u'Several assumptions underlying arguments in support of the contention that differences in income & wealth "matter" are explored, focusing on the notion of sibling parity. If it is assumed that wealth itself matters, primarily as a function of the well-being it provides, can it then be assumed that differences or inequalities in wealth matter? The idea of "permissible disparity" is considered & related to ideas about luck, natural adversity, & individual responsibility. It is suggested that sibling wealth parity should matter, but only ceteris paribus, conditional on its ability to deliver sibling parity in well-being. Additionally, sibling parity is argued to be constrained by personal responsibility; extensions to nonsibling parity are entertained. K. Hyatt Stewart', u'attribution': u'Sociological Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u'For something to matter in the general sense, it looks like its presence or occurrence must have positive (or negative) moral value, and its absence or nonoccurrence must accordingly be an object of moral concern (or approbation). (Here it is important to recall that I have advanced no argument to suggest that even sibling parity, of either wealth or well-being-even when constrained by personal responsibility-should matter in the more specific, enforceable, sense.) What is in question is not whether Ben has a right to such parity, but whether I and/or others exercise our rightful liberties wrongly in withholding it from him.', u'attribution': u'ProQuest Religion'}]}

u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Web of Science', u'sequence': 2}, {u'url': u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://www.scopus.com', u'dbid': u'BKL', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Scopus', u'sequence': 3}], u'issns': [u'0265-0525'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'Data from the March Current Population Surveys, 1968-1999, are drawn on to investigate changes in wage inequality & its impact in the US, comparing within- & between-group statistics for whites & blacks & men & women. Wage differentials by years of schooling & job experience are also documented. A steadily growing wage inequality within & between races & genders is revealed, along with changes in the wage premiums accompanying higher education & greater labor market experience. A distinction is made between the concepts of "skills" & "abilities," &, holding preferences constant, the relation of each to incentives (to invest in more education or job training to improve skills), wages, & incomes is assessed. Although increases in the high school/college wage differential have prompted increased educational attainment, the same "incentive" has also resulted in increasing the proportion of males at the lowest wage potential who do not work at all. The relationship between opportunity & achievement is discussed, & it is argued that, although overall wage inequalities between genders & races have increased, this has created greater incentives & opportunities for achievement; as wages across racial & gender groups have become more equal, so have economic opportunities, though measured economic outcomes have become less equal. 9 Tables. K. Hyatt Stewart', u'attribution': u'Sociological Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u"[...] we come to individual labor income. Since the 1960s, black men and black and white women have each gained between 10 and 20 percentile points in the distribution of white men's wages.", u'attribution': u'ProQuest Religion'}, {u'abstract': u'Examines trends in wage rates showing increasing equality between women and men and between blacks and whites; this has coincided with the growing differentials among those of the same race and gender. Also summarizes responses in levels of education that have accompanied changes in education wage premiums, which declined in the 1970s and then increased sharply thereafter; shows how the trend of increasing differences in time worked between those with high wages and those with low wages runs parallel to the trend in the high-to-low wage differential. (Original abstract - amended)', u'attribution': u'Applied Social Sciences Index and Abstracts (ASSIA)'}]}
