u'BKL', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Scopus', u'sequence': 2}], u'issns': [u'0022-3816'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'Cosmopolitans have criticized Rawls\' Law of Peoples for abandoning the egalitarianism of A Theory of Justice, a retreat they trace to his concern to articulate justice as fairness as a freestanding political conception. Yet the comprehensive liberalisms they propose to underwrite as global distributive principles fall short to the extent that they neglect Kant\'s defense in the Doctrine of Right (1797) of property rights as a "permissive law (lex permissiva) of practical reason." Were Rawls\' critics to utilize this resource, the law of peoples might be refashioned in a manner both affirming Rawls\' earlier universalism and immune to claims that any comprehensive liberalism must betray its commitments to toleration and reciprocity. Yet the comprehensive liberalisms they propose to underwrite as global distributive principles fall short to the extent that they neglect Kant\'s defense in the Doctrine of Right (1797) of property rights as a "permissive law (lex permissiva) of practical reason." Were Rawls\' critics to utilize this resource, the law of peoples might be refashioned in a manner both affirming Rawls\' earlier universalism and immune to claims that any comprehensive liberalism must betray its commitments to toleration and reciprocity.', u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}, {u'abstract': u'Cosmopolitans have criticized Rawls\' Law of Peoples for abandoning the egalitarianism of A Theory of Justice, a retreat they trace to his concern to articulate justice as fairness as a freestanding political conception. Yet the comprehensive liberalisms they propose to underwrite as global distributive principles fall short to the extent that they neglect Kant\'s defense in the Doctrine of Right (1797) of property rights as a "permissive law (lex permissiva) of practical reason." Were Rawls\' critics to utilize this resource, the law of peoples might be refashioned in a manner both affirming Rawls\' earlier universalism and immune to claims that any comprehensive liberalism must betray its commitments to toleration and reciprocity.', u'attribution': u''}]}

u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/wpsa/advanced?accountid=14434', u'dbid': u'7UB', u'source_types': [u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Worldwide Political Science Abstracts', u'sequence': 1}, {u'url': u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://apps.webofknowledge.com/WOS_GeneralSearch_input.do?last_prod=WOS&product=WOS&highlighted_tab=WOS&search_mode=GeneralSearch', u'dbid': u'EGQ', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Web of Science', u'sequence': 2}, {u'url': u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://www.scopus.com', u'dbid': u'BKL', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Scopus', u'sequence': 3}], u'issns': [u'0265-0525'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'It might be held that the good-enough level is the level that enables a person to attain a stipulated amount of pleasure or degree of life-plan fulfillment over the course of her life. Alternatively, the good-enough level might be defined in comparative terms. For example, it might be stipulated that everyone has enough income and wealth when nobody has less than some fraction of the average level. Focuses on noncomparative versions of the sufficiency doctrine; these versions are more interesting and plausible than their comparative counterparts. (Original abstract - amended)', u'attribution': u'Applied Social Sciences Index and Abstracts (ASSIA)'}, {u'abstract': u'Writing about the distribution of money and commodities in contemporary democracies, political theorist Michael Walzer observes that insufficient income excludes a citizen from full membership in society.1 Since the norm of democratic equality requires that all citizens should enjoy the same full membership, Walzer argues, by one means or another all citizens must be assured a sufficient level of money. [...] there are some things that money should not be able to buy: in any society, the social meanings of particular goods rule out their exchange by sale.', u'attribution': u'ProQuest Religion'}, {u'abstract': u'In an analysis of the just transfer of distributable resources, evaluated is Michael Walzer\'s (1983) version of "sufficientarianism," ie, the principle that the distribution of resources is just "if & only if everyone has enough." Three claims connected to this idea are discussed, focusing on noncomparative versions of the sufficiency doctrine (without comparison of one\'s level of income or wealth to others). Although on the surface, the sufficientarian approach conforms to the antipoverty focus of welfare policies & attempts to define an acceptable standard of living above which, according to the principles of social justice, none should be allowed to fall, it is argued that in reality, it falls short. Questions are raised regarding consumption above the line of sufficiency; the moral importance of being "comparatively" better off than another person; determination of a "good-enough" level of income; & responsibility-based objections to the sufficiency doctrine. Problems with both the Walzerian & the more general doctrine of sufficientarianism are identified, contending that neither offers a morally sound way of determining justice when justice requires forced transfers of wealth from the rich to the poor. A more feasible approach to the justice of transfers is offered based on the notion of "prioritarian justice" & linked to the idea of individual responsibility. K. Hyatt Stewart', u'attribution': u'Worldwide Political Science Abstracts'}]}

u'attribution': u'Materials Research Database'}, {u'abstract': u"This article describes the feasibility of researchinto the relation between values of farmers andsustainability for the Dutch Ministry of Agricultureand the Dutch Federation of Agricultural andHorticultural Organisations.Firstly, a theoretical framework describes differentlevels of motivation behind conduct and choices. Itenables exploration and analysis of individualinterviews with small groups of conventional andecological farmers. The aim is to find out what theirbasic convictions regarding nature and sustainabilityare, and to analyze the relation between theseconvictions and the actual choices they make in theirfarming practice. The research shows that for somefarmers, differences in farming practice go back to themotivation level of moral convictions about what is`good farming'. For others, the motivations for aspecific farming practice are more pragmatic or`superficial'. This knowledge can be of significancefor the process of policy making.Secondly, this research demonstrates thatinvestigation into the relation between values andbehavioral choices is possible. The analysis ofinterviews among a small group of farmers gives anidea of the importance of personal values in additionto (and sometimes of more importance than) economicconsiderations. Due to the restricted size of theresearch population, however, these conclusions are oflimited generalizability. Finally, in order to make alarger research agenda possible, the research methodology isevaluated on the basis of scientific criteria.", u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u"\xa0 This article describes the feasibility of research into the relation between values of farmers and sustainability for the Dutch Ministry of Agriculture and the Dutch Federation of Agricultural and Horticultural Organisations. Firstly, a theoretical framework describes different levels of motivation behind conduct and choices. It enables exploration and analysis of individual interviews with small groups of conventional and ecological farmers. The aim is to find out what their basic convictions regarding nature and sustainability are, and to analyze the relation between these convictions and the actual choices they make in their farming practice. The research shows that for some farmers, differences in farming practice go back to the motivation level of moral convictions about what is 'good farming'. For others, the motivations for a specific farming practice are more pragmatic or 'superficial'. This knowledge can be of significance for the process of policy making. Secondly, this research demonstrates that investigation into the relation between values and behavioral choices is possible. The analysis of interviews among a small group of farmers gives an idea of the importance of personal values in addition to (and sometimes of more importance than) economic considerations. Due to the restricted size of the research population, however, these conclusions are of limited generalizability. Finally, in order to make a larger research agenda possible, the research methodology is evaluated on the basis of scientific criteria. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]", u'attribution': u'ProQuest Environmental Science Journals'}, {u'abstract': u"This article describes the feasibility of research into the relation between values of farmers and sustainability for the Dutch Ministry of Agriculture and the Dutch Federation of Agricultural and Horticultural Organisations. Firstly, a theoretical framework describes different levels of motivation behind conduct and choices. It enables exploration and analysis of individual interviews with small groups of conventional and ecological farmers. The aim is to find out what their basic convictions regarding nature and sustainability are, and to analyze the relation between these convictions and the actual choices they make in their farming practice. The research shows that for some farmers, differences in farming practice go back to the motivation level of moral convictions about what is 'good farming'. For others, the motivations for a specific fanning practice are more pragmatic or 'superficial'. This knowledge can be of significance for the process of policy making. Secondly, this research demonstrates that investigation into the relation between values and behavioral choices is possible. The analysis of interviews among a small group of farmers gives an idea of the importance of personal values in addition to (and sometimes of more importance than) economic considerations. Due to the restricted size of ther research population, however, these conclusions are of limited generalizability. Finally, in order to make a larger research agenda possible, the research methodology is evaluated on the basis of scientific criteria.", u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}]}

u'name': u'ProQuest Criminal Justice', u'sequence': 1}, {u'url': u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://www.scopus.com', u'dbid': u'BKL', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Scopus', u'sequence': 2}], u'issns': [u'0885-7466'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'\xa0 In multiethnic societies, issues of justice and fairness have become the focus of intense public debate. Although current psychological theories of distributive and procedural justice concentrate on multiple normative rules that guide allocation decisions, there is little research that focuses on the particular relationship between immigrants as recipients and members of the host society as allocators. In the present study Germans were asked about their opinions as to what Turkish immigrants in Germany deserve or are entitled to and to which degree they pose a threat to German culture. Political orientation of the allocator turns out to be an important predictor of how distributive and procedural justice concerns are evaluated. Both conservatives and liberals exhibit a different conception of what counts as distributive justice. With regard to procedural justice, however, liberals and conservatives did not differ much. Moreover, perceived threat to German culture is significantly related to distributive justice but not to procedural justice.[PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]', u'attribution': u'ProQuest Central Basic'}, {u'abstract': u'In multiethnic societies, issues of justice & fairness have become the focus of intense public debate. Although current psychological theories of distributive & procedural justice concentrate on multiple normative rules that guide allocation decisions, there is little research that focuses on the particular relationship between immigrants as recipients & members of the host society as allocators. In the present study, Germans were asked about their opinions as to what Turkish immigrants in Germany deserve or are entitled to & to which degree they pose a threat to German culture. Political orientation of the allocator turns out to be an important predictor of how distributive & procedural justice concerns are evaluated. Both conservatives & liberals exhibit a different conception of what counts as distributive justice. With regard to procedural justice, however, liberals & conservatives did not differ much. Moreover, perceived threat to German culture is significantly related to distributive justice but not to procedural justice. 2 Tables, 33 References. u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://apps.webofknowledge.com/WOS_GeneralSearch_input.do?last_prod=WOS&product=WOS&highlighted_tab=WOS&search_mode=GeneralSearch', u'dbid': u'EGQ', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Web of Science', u'sequence': 2}], u'issns': [u'0048-3915'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'\xa0 Blake argues that a globally impartial liberal theory is not incompatible with distinct principles of distributive justice applicable only within the national context. A concern with relative economic shares, he argues, is a plausible interpretation of liberal principles only when those principles are applied to individuals who share liability to the coercive network of state governance.', u'attribution': u'Curriculum Essentials'}, {u'abstract': u'Offers a fresh way for liberalism to deal with problems created by state borders. John Rawls\'s theory of justice (1971) & principle of autonomy are drawn upon to argue that globally impartial liberal theory is not incompatible with principles of distributive justice, applicable solely within the national context. A concern with relative economic shares is seen as a credible interpretation of liberal principles "only when those principles are applied to individuals who share liability to the coercive network of state governance," but not required when individuals do not share links of citizenship. Distinctions are made between relative/absolute deprivation; partial/impartial justificatory strategies, & institutional/noninstitutional theory. The importance of autonomy as a value of liberal political philosophy is examined, along with morally acceptable forms of state coercion. It is argued that it is possible to defend principles of sufficiency in the international arena & domestic principles of distributive equality because both can be viewed as specific implications of impartial principles in distinct institutional contexts. J. Lindroth', u'attribution': u'Worldwide Political Science Abstracts'}]}

renewal of interest in the liberal tradition in international thought, with particular attention being paid to liberal conceptions of international distributive justice. This article describes and criticizes three different approaches to international distributive justice represented in the recent literature: (1) social liberalism, which takes the nation-state as basic and argues for international transfers to the extent necessary to sustain just domestic institutions; (2) laisser-faire liberalism, which, in its redistributivist variant, aims to rectify injustices arising from the unequal appropriation of natural resources; and (3) cosmopolitan liberalism, which takes each individual's interests as equally deserving of concern in the design of global (and sectional) institutions.", u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u"In recent pars there has been a renewal of interest in the liberal tradition in international thought, with particular attention being paid to liberal conceptions of international distributive justice. This article describes and criticizes three different approaches to international distributive justice represented in the recent literature: (1) social liberalism, which takes the nation-state as basic and argues for international transfers to the extent necessary to sustain just domestic institutions; (2) laissez-faire liberalism, which, in its redistributivist variant, aims to rectify injustices arising from the unequal appropriation of natural resources; and (3) cosmopolitan liberalism, which takes each individual's interests as equally deserving of concern in the design of global (and sectional) institutions.", u'attribution': u'Curriculum Essentials'}]}

ideology is one of the most analyzed themes in visual sociology. Despite this, there exists a serious omission in our understanding of the visual processes used to create ideology. This article, through the analysis of the role of visual juxtaposition & sequencing in the British government publication, The Colonies in Pictures, documents a previously ignored mechanism for ideology formation. I argue that the publication reconstructs British colonial ideology by shifting the marker used to distinguish between British & non-British from ethnicity to culture. Such a reconstruction was necessitated by the historical circumstances following WWII & enabled the British to retain economic control over the colonies while granting political autonomy. 5 Figures, 35 References. Adapted from the source document.', u'attribution': u'Sociological Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u"ABSTRACT IN FRENCH: Le lien entre l'image et l'id\xe9ologie est un des th\xe8mes les plus \xe9tudi\xe9s en sociologie visuelle. Il existe n\xe9anmoins une s\xe9rieuse lacune dans notre compr\xe9hension des proc\xe9d\xe9s visuels auxquels on a recours pour cr\xe9er une id\xe9ologie. Cet article, au moyen d'une analyse du r\xf4le de la juxtaposition et de l'encha\xeenement visuels dans la publication gouvernementale britannique The Colonies in Pictures, atteste un m\xe9canisme jusqu'ici ignor\xe9 dans la formation de l'id\xe9ologie. Je soutiens que la publication reconstruit une id\xe9ologie coloniale britannique en faisant passer de l'ethnicit\xe9 \xe0 la culture le marqueur utilis\xe9 pour distinguer le britannique du non-britannique. Une telle reconstruction avait \xe9t\xe9 rendue n\xe9cessaire en raison du contexte historique qui a suivi la Deuxi\xe8me Guerre mondiale et a permis aux Britanniques de conserver une mainmise sur l'\xe9conomie des colonies tout en leur accordant une autonomie politique. // ABSTRACT IN ENGLISH: The connection between image and ideology is one of the most analysed themes in visual sociology. Despite this, there exists a serious omission in our understanding of the visual processes used to create ideology. This article, through the analysis of the role of visual juxtaposition and sequencing in the British government publication The Colonies in Pictures, documents a previously ignored mechanism for ideology formation. I argue that the publication reconstructs British colonial ideology by shifting the marker used to distinguish between British and non-British from ethnicity to culture. Such a reconstruction was necessitated by the historical circumstances following World War II and enabled the British to retain economic control over the colonies while granting political autonomy. Despite this, there exists a serious omission in our understanding of the visual processes used to create ideology. This article, through the analysis of the role of visual juxtaposition and sequencing in the British government publication The Colonies in Pictures, documents a previously ignored mechanism for ideology formation. I argue that the publication reconstructs British colonial ideology by shifting the marker used to distinguish between British and non-British from ethnicity to culture. u'BKL', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Scopus', u'sequence': 3}], u'issns': [u'0026-1068'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'The paper discusses the problem of global distributive justice. It proposes to distinguish between principles for the domestic & for the global or intersocietal distribution of wealth. It is argued that there may be a plurality of partly diverging domestic conceptions of distributive justice, not all of which need to be liberal egalitarian conceptions. It is maintained, however, that principles regulating the intersocietal distribution of wealth have to be egalitarian principles. This claim is defended against Rawls\'s argument in The Law of Peoples that egalitarian principles of distributive justice should not be applied globally. Moreover, it is explained in detail, why Rawls\'s "duty of assistance to burdened societies" cannot be an appropriate substitute for a global principle of distributive justice. 17 References. Adapted from the source document.', u'attribution': u'Worldwide Political Science Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u'The paper discusses the problem of global distributive justice. It proposes to distinguish between principles for the domestic and for the global or intersocietal distribution of wealth. It is argued that there may be a plurality of partly diverging domestic conceptions of distributive justice, not all of which need to be liberal egalitarian conceptions. It is maintained, however, that principles regulating the intersocietal distribution of wealth have to be egalitarian principles. This claim is defended against Rawls\'s argument in The Law of Peoples that egalitarian principles of distributive justice should not be applied globally. Moreover, it is explained in detail, why Rawls\'s "duty of assistance to burdened societies" cannot be an appropriate substitute for a global principle of distributive justice.', u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}]}

u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Web of Science', u'sequence': 2}, {u'url': u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://www.scopus.com', u'dbid': u'BKL', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Scopus', u'sequence': 3}], u'issns': [u'0167-4544'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u"\xa0 In The Ethics of International Business (1989) Tom Donaldson says that, in general, basic international human rights impose correlative duties not only on individuals and nations, but also on multinational corporations. However, Donaldson denies that the corporate duty to render aid to those deprived of basic human rights is a minimal moral mandate, except in certain special circumstances. This argument is challenged with a claim that distributive justice establishes a basis for holding multinational corporations to such a duty as well. The root idea advocated is that Rawls' theory of justice can be deployed - beyond its original intent yet in line with its spirit - to underwrite a prima facie obligation of international business to render aid to ameliorate suffering on behalf of the inhabitants of developing countries in which they operate.", u'attribution': u'ProQuest Health Management'}, {u'abstract': u"This article challenges an argument from Tom Donaldson's recent book The Ethics of International Business with a claim that distributive justice, deemed in many circles to impose a duty of mutual aid on individuals and nations, establishes a basis for holding multinational corporations to such a duty as well. The root idea I advocate is that Rawls' theory of justice can be deployed - beyond its original intent yet in line with its spirit - to underwrite a prima facie obligation of international business to render aid to ameliorate suffering on behalf of the inhabitants of developing countries in which they operate.", u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}, {u'abstract': u"This article challenges an argument from Tom Donaldson's recent book The Ethics of International Business with a claim that distributive justice, deemed in many circles to impose a duty of mutual aid on individuals and nations, establishes a basis for holding multinational corporations to such a duty as well. The root idea I advocate is that Rawls' theory of justice can be deployed - beyond its original intent yet in line with its spirit - to underwrite a prima facie obligation of international business to render aid to ameliorate suffering on behalf of the inhabitants of developing countries in which they operate.", u'attribution': u''}]}

u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Web of Science', u'sequence': 2}, {u'url': u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://www.scopus.com', u'dbid': u'BKL', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Scopus', u'sequence': 3}], u'issns': [u'0265-0525'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'Reviews arguments for & against the contention that the welfare state -- through the direct redistribution of income from the wealthy to the poor -- actually helps those who are disadvantaged. Statistical data for the US across the 1980s-1990s reveal that only a small proportion of the gross domestic product (GDP) was directed toward antipoverty programs, social welfare spending primarily benefited the upper-middle class, & even direct redistribution programs (eg, Aid to Families with Dependent Children & food stamps) represented less than .02% of the GDP annually. Conservative & libertarian arguments that the welfare state actually worsens the situation of the poor are examined, highlighting Charles Murray\'s Losing Ground: American Social Policy, 1950-1980 (2nd edition, 1994), & ultimately rejected. Evidence is presented to demonstrate that current welfare recipients (at least those who are domestic citizens) do benefit from direct transfers; however, benefits to the poor in general or to foreign citizens are less certain. It is concluded that the doctrine of "impersonal consequentialism" actually militates against the welfare state, & suggests that its secondary consequences may be more negative than positive for immigrants & future generations as a whole. K. Hyatt Stewart', u'attribution': u'Worldwide Political Science Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u'Reviews arguments for & against the contention that the welfare state -- through the direct redistribution of income from the wealthy to the poor -- actually helps those who are disadvantaged. Statistical data for the US across the 1980s-1990s reveal that only a small proportion of the gross domestic product (GDP) was directed toward antipoverty programs, social welfare spending primarily benefited the upper-middle class, & even direct redistribution programs (eg, Aid to Families with Dependent Children & food stamps) represented less than .02% of the GDP annually. Conservative & libertarian arguments that the welfare state actually worsens the situation of the poor are examined, highlighting Charles Murray\'s Losing Ground: American Social Policy, 1950-1980 (2nd edition, 1994), & ultimately rejected. Evidence is presented to demonstrate that current welfare recipients (at least those who are domestic citizens) do benefit from direct transfers; however, benefits to the poor in general or to foreign citizens are less certain. It is concluded that the doctrine of "impersonal consequentialism" actually militates against the welfare state, & suggests that its secondary consequences may be more negative than positive for immigrants & future generations as a whole. K. Hyatt Stewart', u'attribution': u'Sociological Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u'Looks at how much the welfare state transfers to the poor, which turns out to be a surprisingly small sum relative to the stock of wealth. Considers the empirical evidence for the traditional conservative argument that the welfare state is bad for the poor. In general, the evidence indicates that current recipients of welfare benefit from the transfers, contrary to what Murray and some other critics have suggested. Nonetheless, the welfare state appears to harm the interests of future generations and foreign citizens, and in this regard it does not help the poor more generally. (Original abstract - amended)', u'attribution': u'Applied Social Sciences Index and Abstracts (ASSIA)'}, {u'abstract': u'Another estimate is that U.S. antipoverty expenditures comprised roughly 4 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) in 1992.2 The net effects of the U.S. Social Security system are complex, and I do not count them as part of the welfare state in this essay.3 In any case, most of this redistribution is across generations rather than to the poor per se. The American welfare program that comes closest to representing a pure transfer payment is the program that, before the Clinton-era welfare reforms, was called AFDC, or Aid to Families with Dependent Children. The relatively poor Faeroe islands have recently stated their intent to secede from Denmark, and the Danes have responded by threatening to cut off all aid and subsidies within a few years of secession.30 These global comparisons further support suspicions that the case for the welfare state is not based in egalitarian reasoning.', u'attribution': u'ProQuest Religion'}]}

u'BKL', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Scopus', u'sequence': 3}], u'issns': [u'0273-2173'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u"The basic premise of this article is that the revival and increasing acceptance of the concept of cultural pluralism (and its contemporary variant, multiculturalism) in popular and academic discourses today should be investigated as a problem in the sociology of knowledge. In this context, this article discusses briefly how cultural pluralism is used in popular and academic discourses today. Then, it identifies the normative structure of, and the domain assumptions underpinning, the concept. The article constructs an argument that the concept lacks conceptual precision and analytical rigor; that its ontological claims for race and ethnicity cannot be justified; and that it is epistemologically incoherent, as shown by its internal contradictions. The article concludes that the ideological implications of the concept should be investigated and that discourses on cultural pluralism, generally, would benefit by resurrecting Milton Gordon's concept of the eth - class.", u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u"The basic premise of this article is that the revival and increasing acceptance of the concept of cultural pluralism (and its contemporary variant, multiculturalism) in popular and academic discourses today should be investigated as a problem in the sociology of knowledge. In this context, this article discusses briefly how cultural pluralism is used in popular and academic discourses today. Then, it identifies the normative structure of and the domain assumptions underpinning, the concept The article constructs an argument that the concept lacks conceptual precision and analytical rigor; that its ontological claims for race and ethnicity cannot be justified; and that it is epistemologically incoherent, as shown by its internal contradictions. The article concludes that the ideological implications of the concept should be investigated and that discourses on cultural pluralism, generally, would benefit by resurrecting Milton Gordon's concept of the eth-class.", u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}, {u'abstract': u"Argues that the revival & increasing acceptance of the concept of cultural pluralism (& its contemporary variant, multiculturalism) in popular & academic discourses today should be investigated as a problem in the sociology of knowledge. Briefly discussed in this context is how cultural pluralism is used in popular & academic discourses today. The normative structure of, & domain assumptions underpinning, the concept are identified. Analysis, however, suggests that the concept lacks conceptual precision & analytical rigor; its ontological claims for race & ethnicity cannot be justified; & it is epistemologically incoherent, as shown by its internal contradictions. It is concluded that the ideological implications of the concept should be investigated, & that discourses on cultural pluralism, generally, would benefit by resurrecting Milton Gordon's (1964) concept of the eth-class. 64 References. Adapted from the source document.", u'attribution': u'Sociological Abstracts'}]}

Animals are not only valuable instrumentally or indirectly, but in themselves. Less has been written about interest conflicts between humans and other animals, and the use of animals in practice. The motive of this paper is to analyze different approaches to interest conflicts. It concentrates on six models, which are the rights model, the interest model, the mental complexity model, the special relations model, the multi-criteria model, and the contextual model. Of these, the contextual model is the strongest, and carries clear consequences for the practical use of animals.', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'\xa0 Animal ethics has presented convincing arguments for the individual value of animals. It concentrates on six models, which are the rights model, the interest model, the mental complexity model, the special relations model, the multi-criteria model, and the contextual model. Of these, the contextual model is the strongest, and carries clear consequences for the practical use of animals. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]', u'attribution': u'ProQuest Health Management'}, {u'abstract': u'Animal ethics has presented convincing arguments for the individual value of animals. Animals are not only valuable instrumentally or indirectly, but in themselves. Less has been written about interest conflicts between humans and other animals, and the use of animals in practice. The motive of this paper is to analyze different approaches to interest conflicts. It concentrates on six models, which are the rights model, the interest model, the mental complexity model, the special relations model, the multi-criteria model, and the contextual model. Of these, the contextual model is the strongest, and carries clear consequences for the practical use of animals.', u'attribution': u''}]}

The strong form of their objection holds that both theories absurdly entail a duty to intervene in wild predation. The weak form holds that animal welfarists must at least regard predation as bad, and that this stance reflects an arrogance toward nature that true environmentalists should reject. This paper disputes both versions of the predation critique. Animal welfarists are not committed to protecting the rabbit from the fox, nor do their principles implicitly deprecate nature.', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'\xa0 Many environmentalists criticize as unecological the emphasis that animal liberationists and animal rights theorists place on preventing animal suffering. The strong form of their objection holds that both theories absurdly entail a duty to intervene in wild predation. The weak form holds that animal welfarists must at least regard predation as bad, and that this stance reflects an arrogance toward nature that true environmentalists should reject. This paper disputes both versions of the predation critique. Animal welfarists are not committed to protecting the rabbit from the fox, nor do their principles implicitly deprecate nature. Reprinted by permission of the publisher.', u'attribution': u''}]}

doesn't harm the animal's welfare. Recent attempts to undermine his argument rely either on the claim that diminishing certain capacities always harms an animal's welfare or on the claim that it always violates an animal's integrity. I argue that these fail. I argue that these fail. 195', u'thumbnail_small': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/sc.gif&issn=1085-6633&client=summon', u'fulltext_link': u'http://tufts.summon.serialssolutions.com/2.0.0/link/0/eLvHCXMwfZ3NSsNAEMeHopeCWK0GrRbyArVpNx9GSsFqgyepWnstu8nuqQQxycH38IHdmWTNIupxZpeQZfIxm_z-MwBseuWNfjwTQi6ZikTE0olgLGAiDVKdm_hKcpb5AqXET4_hy4Yl99eLDpgGgwhZEiVI__R1uiR2cux7elsV0z59Mg0R44oX6xbr8Ki6Zw3Vh9gP1-YM6a2R9GBjtDeETH9DI-ZDX1mpsrCQaqs247-ndASHTR7p3taBP4aOzPvgLFvZmh5s7tuiD92V6VjwcQKfMzEnzJ3vZmMxd7VZK_SNhaRGVRjrFXU79uRVI6xC-wYdz1jfAAPczqDiD5aH55mbUPkS46nrXdNVj65TGCbL9d3DiFa9fauLYGzNkpkDBxxh_Lwk0V52Bm4UCMkyvZWTofAzJWOlsClWLDB5iz1-Ds7vBxv8NXABXRIDEkV3CXvleyWHsE9x-gINhLou', u'publisher': u'JAI Press Inc', u'is_a_i': False, u'thumbnail_large': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=1085-6633&client=summon', u'start_pages': [u'177'], u'eissns': [u'1535-5306'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Publisher'], u'volumes': [u'3'], u'issns': [u'1085-6633'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'The main international standard-setting agencies for ionizing radiation, the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and the International Commission on Radiological Protection (ICRP) both subscribe to principles which (they claim) lead to equitable protection for all generations exposed to radioactive pollution. Yet, when one examines the practices both groups support, it is clear that these practices discriminate against future generations with respect to radioactive pollution. After showing (I) that the IAEA and ICRP rhetoric of equity does not match their policies and practices, the essay argues (2) that current people ought to try to treat members of future generations equitably with respect to protection from radioactive pollution. The essay also argues (3) that current policies of permanent disposal of high-level radioactive waste do not meet the second criterion, and therefore (4) that society ought to investigate whether another strategy for managing the waste would provide better equal protection among all generations.', u'attribution': u''}]}

This article examines the differing traditions & approaches of environmental justice & sustainability, & explores some of their theoretical bases. It also briefly reviews human rights & environmental security issues in order to discern the potential for common ground between the two main traditions. The authors argue that there are indications of convergence between these traditions & that this convergence is happening primarily through the activities of progressive NGOs, academics, & local community organizations worldwide. What is now needed is for governments at local, regional, national, & international levels to learn from these organizations & to seek to embed the central principles & practical approaches of environmental justice within emerging sustainable development policy. 67 References. Adapted from the source document.', u'attribution': u'Worldwide Political Science Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u'In recent years it has become increasingly apparent that the issue of environmental quality is inextricably linked to that of human equality at all scales. This article examines the differing traditions and approaches of environmental justice and sustainability, and explores some of their theoretical bases. It also briefly reviews human rights and environmental security issues in order to discern the potential for common ground between the two main traditions. The authors argue that there are indications of convergence between these traditions and that this convergence is happening primarily through the activities of progressive NGOs, academics and local community organisations world-wide. What is now needed is for governments at local, regional, national and international levels to learn from these organisations and to seek to embed the central principles and practical approaches of environmental justice within emerging sustainable development policy.', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'In recent years it has become increasingly apparent that environmental quality is inextricably linked to human equality at all scales. This article examines the differing traditions & approaches of environmental justice & sustainability, & explores some of their theoretical bases. It also briefly reviews human rights & environmental security issues in order to discern the potential for common ground between the two main traditions. The authors argue that there are indications of convergence between these traditions & that this convergence is happening primarily through the activities of progressive NGOs, academics, & local community organizations worldwide. What is now needed is for governments at local, regional, national, & international levels to learn from these organizations & to seek to embed the central principles & practical approaches of environmental justice within emerging sustainable development policy. 67 References. 36', u'thumbnail_small': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/sc.gif&issn=0163-4275&client=summon', u'fulltext_link': u'http://tufts.summon.serialssolutions.com/2.0.0/link/0/eLvHCXMwnV1LTwIxEJ6oxMRofKBGRCN_YGW33W63CcH4gHgi8YFX0mdiYhaU5cC_ty27gPg4eNxOL91ppt_MfDMDgNFlGKzYBK0wJqFCEmmDsNCcSEGZRkZrzCl2pcQPveTpBXfv0ptF_K3QdmkkveVWQ-mC5k2HVGILd65G74EbIuWSrcVEjXWoWFwSOoYX7c8Ns4UOs3mbFoIEMXLMwpVU8zd77B-Z7h6MylIdz7Cec0zKuGA-Mfl4iYG91MrxnyfYh90CkDauZzfoANZ0VoXtpfkJ0ypsdnxv6-kh3LVEu7OojeNvraZoN9yi582XXzxTjd4w8wMAy7VHFwbwO46g3-08394HxSCGQFo4FgaMEMxEjEJhCBIhw4lMqcLa-k6UWMhoFE0tkoyUa80TEsWMCHUsEsFjad8-g49hhzvCfpb7wj51Ag2dMtf8zSSIJrHdzpSOiMQRToQwmKc1uPiqnMHodTiISDpLtlp11qBe_tYBFy4wJPOxdWUcxE3Zz9LEdS8iFP0iLRRy-qe0DlsRs36Jp--cwUb-MdHnUPGX4BP_S-Xq', u'is_a_i': False, u'thumbnail_large': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=0163-4275&client=summon', u'start_pages': [u'17'], u'eissns': [u'2153-7895'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Index Database', u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'4'], u'databases': [{u'url': u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/socialservices/advanced?accountid=14434', u'dbid': u'7U3', u'source_types': [u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Social Services Abstracts', u'sequence': 1}], u'issns': [u'0163-4275'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'IF ENVIRONMENTALISTS ARE TO COMBAT EFFECTIVELY THE CONTINUING ENVIRONMENTAL DECAY RESULTING FROM INTENSE HUMAN EXPLOITATION OF NATURE, THEY NEED A PLAUSIBLE AND COHERENT RATIONALE FOR PRESERVING SENSITIVE AREAS AND OTHER SPECIES. THIS NEED IS ILLUSTRATED BY REFERENCE TO TWO EXAMPLES OF CONTROVERSIES CONCERNING LARGE PUBLIC PROJECTS IN WILDERNESS AREAS.', u'attribution': u'Worldwide Political Science Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u'Both cost-benefit analysis and utilitarian theory are inadequate rationales for proper human exploitation of nature; so too is the suggestion by some environmentalists to ascribe rights to animals. Expanding the number and types of rights holders ignores the question of which individual rights take precedence over others. An environmental ethic must support the holistic function of an ecosystem; this holistic ethic cannot emanate from an individualistic framework of rights.', u'attribution': u'ProQuest Environmental Science Collection'}, {u'abstract': u'If environmentalists are to effectively combat the continuing environmental decay resulting from increasingly more intense human exploitation of nature, they need a plausible & coherent rationale for preserving sensitive areas & other species. This need is illustrated by reference to two examples of controversies concerning large public projects in wilderness areas. A number of environmentalists have suggested that ascriptions of rights to nonhuman animals, plants, & other natural objects be provided. However, such ascriptions can only be effective if they are supported by a general theory of rights. Although no such general theory is developed, four minimal conditions are noted that must be fulfilled by rights holders as entailments of the concept of a right. No appeals to rights of nonhumans can simultaneously fulfill these four minimal conditions & satisfy the need for a coherent rationale for environmental preservation. A distinction is drawn between the concern of vegetarians & antivivisectionists who rest their case for animal rights on the analogy of animal suffering, & the concern of environmentalists to protect the integrity of holistic ecosystems. Modified HA.', u'attribution': u'Social Services Abstracts'}]}

SSL Title: The Liberation of Nature?

185', u'thumbnail_small': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/sc.gif&issn=1085-6633&client=summon', u'fulltext_link': u'http://tufts.summon.serialssolutions.com/2.0.0/link/0/eLvHCXMwfZ1ba8IwFMcPsr0IYxe3spvQL6DGpk0jiKCbZS8bu4ivkisIWoatsH37JamZZWx7TALh0JCTk-b3PwcAR13U-eETZIxEIhKkGO0nImYpllpqIQVBinNs9c4vT-RtjrN7OmmALzBoIUtHCbo3fRMu8ZXqxQjbU9aK9voRsRjXYDLbYx3IZfesoHpi6-HWOUN3amQnMPfaG4dMf0Mj_kdfudVlUUOqa7kZ_zXpFI53cWQ4rhb-DBoqb0Ew3cvWzOBu3xYtaD77igWf59Ad8tEj23wsi_Wwx0ehabJchuN8uWYr3_NqL-2FbV1AO5vO7h46zp7Fe5WeYuGNwQEcMYvJ56WT08lLCKnQmnHj0pQJpJhKjatTOiGpJpQOIoquIPh9suu_Bm6g6TK6Or7tFg7KzVa14dB9wS90Upi-', u'publisher': u'JAI Press Inc', u'is_a_i': False, u'thumbnail_large': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=1085-6633&client=summon', u'start_pages': [u'169'], u'eissns': [u'1535-5306'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Publisher'], u'volumes': [u'2'], u'issns': [u'1085-6633'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'There is no doubt that Marx and Engels rejected animal rights. However, they did embrace the communist principle, "From each according to his abilities, to each according to his need." Furthermore, they acknowledged that nonhuman animals have needs. So the principle can enjoin us to respect animals\' needs, even if they lack certain abilities (e.g., tool-making, perhaps even self-consciousness). I argue that it is essentially speciesist to restrict this principle to human beings, and that its acceptance implies either animal rights or a substantive equivalent. Marxism may have to undergo a profound dialectical transformation in light of the implications of its own maxim.', u'attribution': u''}]}

that it is sometimes right to let people starve in order to save nature is argued to be inconclusive at best; some alternative responses to population growth are also presented. The very concept of development implies that authentic development, being socially and ecologically sustainable, will seldom conflict with saving nature (sections 1 and 2). While Rolston's argument about excessive capture of net primary product is fallacious, his view should be endorsed about the wrongness of 'development' in areas where sustainable development is impossible, but not unqualifiedly endorsed about those areas where it is feasible (section 3). Important as policies promoting sustainable levels of population are, representing population growth as a cancer is misguided, and could engender indifference to suffering (sections 4 and 5). u'publisher': u'White Horse Press', u'page_counts': [u'9'], u'is_a_i': False, u'thumbnail_large': u'http://covers-cdn.summon.serialssolutions.com/index.aspx?isbn=/lc.gif&issn=0963-2719&client=summon', u'start_pages': [u'113'], u'eissns': [u'1752-7015'], u'content_types': [u'Journal Article'], u'source_types': [u'Publisher', u'Enrichment Source', u'Aggregation Database'], u'volumes': [u'1'], u'issns': [u'0963-2719'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u"Apparent clashes of interest between 'deep ecologists' and 'animal liberationists' can be understood as differences in emphasis rather than conflicts of principle, although it is only too easy for campaigners to regard as rivals good causes other than their own. Moral principles are part of a larger whole, within which they can be related, rather than absolute all-purpose rules of right conduct. This is illustrated using the practical dilemma which often occurs in conservation management, of whether or not to cull animals that are damaging their habitat by overgrazing. Here, and in general, when we are faced with a choice between two evils, the need for scrupulous discrimination and honesty cannot be overstated; but it is not a worthy option to retreat behind moral principles of limited application.", u'attribution': u''}]}

philosophers have claimed that environmental holism in general, and Leopold\'s Land Ethic in particular, ought to be rejected on the basis that it has fascistic implications. I argue that the land Ethic is not tantamount to environmental fascism because Leopold\'s moral theory accounts for the moral standing of the individual as well as "the land," a holistic ethic better protects and defends the individual in the long-run, and the term "fascism" is misapplied in this case.', u'attribution': u''}]}

u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Web of Science', u'sequence': 2}, {u'url': u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://www.scopus.com', u'dbid': u'BKL', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Scopus', u'sequence': 3}], u'issns': [u'0163-4275'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u"Governments of all nations presume they possess full discretionary policy-making powers over the lands and waters within their geopolitical boundaries. At least one global environmental issue - the rapid loss of the world's biodiversity, the sixth major mass extinction event in geological time - challenges the legitimacy of this presumption. Increment by increment, the present generation is depleting the world's biodiversity by way of altering species' habitats for the sake of short term economic gain. When biodiversity is understood as an essential environmental condition - essential in the long term because it is the source of the biological resources upon which humans depend - then the strongly differential distribution of benefits and burdens between generations raises an issue of intergenerational justice. We receive the short-term benefits of economic development; future generations will receive the resulting burden of a biosphere in which one of the life-support systems necessary for humanity will have been compromised. Using Ronald Dworkin's conceptions of distributive justice, it can be demonstrated that constitutional constraints on the discretionary powers of governments, for the sake of intergenerational justice, are entirely consistent with central tenets of liberal democracy. As a result, we should abandon to some extent the presumption that governments have full jurisdiction over the lands and waters within their boundaries.", u'attribution': u'Environmental Sciences and Pollution Management'}, {u'abstract': u"Governments of all nations presume they possess full discretionary policy-making powers over the lands and waters within their geopolitical boundaries. At least one global environmental issue-the rapid loss of the world's biodiversity, the sixth major mass extinction event in geological time-challenges the legitimacy of this presumption. Increment by increment, the present generation is depleting the world's biodiversity by way of altering species' habitats for the sake of short term economic gain. When biodiversity is understood as an essential environmental condition-essential in the long term because it is the source of the biological resources upon which humans depend-then the strongly differential distribution of benefits and burdens between generations raises an issue of intergenerational justice. We receive the short-term benefits of economic development; future generations will receive the resulting burden of a biosphere in which one of the life-support systems necessary for humanity will have been compromised. Using Ronald Dworkin's conceptions of distributive justice, it can be demonstrated that constitutional constraints on the discretionary powers of governments, for the sake of intergenerational justice, are entirely consistent with central tenets of liberal democracy. As a result, we should abandon to some extent the presumption that governments have full jurisdiction over the lands and waters within their boundaries.", u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}, {u'abstract': u"\xa0 Governments of all nations presume they possess full discretionary policymaking powers over the lands and waters within their geopolitical boundaries. At least one global environmental issue-the rapid loss of the world's biodiversity, the sixth major mass extinction event in geological time-challenges the legitimacy of this presumption. Increment by increment, the present generation is depleting the world's biodiversity by way of altering species' habitats for the sake of short term economic gain. When biodiversity is understood as an essential environmental condition-essential in the long term because it is the source of the biological resources upon which humans depend-then the strongly differential distribution of benefits and burdens between generations raises an issue of intergenerational justice. We receive the short-term benefits of economic development; future generations will receive the resulting burden of a biosphere in which one of the life-support systems necessary for humanity will have been compromised. Using Ronald Dworkin's conceptions of distributive justice, it can be demonstrated that constitutional constraints on the discretionary powers of governments, for the sake of intergenerational justice, are entirely consistent with central tenets of liberal democracy. As a result, we should abandon to some extent the presumption that governments have full jurisdiction over the lands and waters within their boundaries. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]", u'attribution': u'ProQuest Environmental Science Journals'}]}

u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Web of Science', u'sequence': 2}, {u'url': u'https://login.ezproxy.library.tufts.edu/login?url=http://www.scopus.com', u'dbid': u'BKL', u'source_types': [u'Enrichment Source', u'Index Database'], u'name': u'Scopus', u'sequence': 3}], u'issns': [u'0032-3217'], u'abstracts': [{u'abstract': u'Global climate change has important implications for the way in which benefits and burdens will be distributed amongst present and future generations. As a result it raises important questions of intergenerational justice. It is shown that there is at least one serious problem for those who wish to approach these questions by utilizing familiar principles of justice. This is that such theories often pre-suppose harm-based accounts of injustice which are incompatible with the fact that the very social policies which climatologists and scientists claim will reduce the risks of climate change will also predictably, if indirectly, determine which individuals will live in the future. One proposed solution to this problem is outlined grounded in terms of the notion of collective interests.', u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}, {u'abstract': u'Global climate change raises important questions of intergenerational justice. It is shown that there is at least one serious problem for those who wish to approach these questions by utilizing familiar principles of justice.', u'attribution': u'Platinum: Social Sciences'}, {u'abstract': u'GLOBAL CLIMATE CHANGE HAS IMPORTANT IMPLICATIONS FOR THE WAY IN WHICH BENEFITS AND BURDENS WILL BE DISTRIBUTED AMONGST PRESENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS. AS A RESULT IT RAISES IMPORTANT QUESTIONS OF INTERGENERATIONAL JUSTICE. ONE PROBLEM IS THAT THEORIES OFTEN PRE-SUPPOSE HARM-BASED ACCOUNTS OF INJUSTICE WHICH ARE INCOMPATIBLE WITH THE FACT THAT THE VERY SOCIAL POLICIES WHICH CLIMATOLOGISTS AND SCIENTISTS CLAIM WILL REDUCE THE RISKS OF CLIMATE CHANGE WILL ALSO PREDICTABLY, IF INDIRECTLY, DETERMINE WHICH INDIVIDUALS WILL LIVE IN THE FUTURE.', u'attribution': u'Worldwide Political Science Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u'Global climate change raises important questions concerning intergenerational justice. For those who wish to approach these questions by using familiar principles of justice, there is at least one serious problem: such theories often presuppose harm-based accounts of injustice which are incompatible with the fact that the very social policies which climatologists and scientists claim will reduce the risks of climate change will also predictably, if indirectly, determine which individuals will live in the future. A possible solution to this problem is outlined, grounded in terms of the notion of collective interests. (Original abstract - amended)', u'attribution': u'British Humanities Index (BHI)'}]}

This is usually said to be justified by appealing to the scientific merit of the research. This article looks at notions of scientific merit, queries whether they are as clear-cut as commonly supposed, and argues that with contemporary conceptions it is too easy for any research to count as meritorious. A tightening of the notion of scientific merit is suggested, providing a ground for rejection of certain psychological research.', u'attribution': u''}]}

include friendships in the life of a consequentialist. The optimal ways depend on the version of consequentialism, the situation, and the capacities of the individuals involved. But it is highly likely that thriving friendships play a large role in the best lives that reasonable consequentialists can lead. An overriding commitment to a consequentialist view encourages a reasonable and well informed person to maintain strong close relationships. (Quotes from original text)', u'attribution': u'British Humanities Index (BHI)'}]}

(Original abstract - amended)', u'attribution': u'Applied Social Sciences Index and Abstracts (ASSIA)'}, {u'abstract': u"In response to the burgeoning interest in ethnic health issues & related published research, a number of recent contributors have attempted to clarify or systematize the usage of overarching terminology like 'ethnicity', 'race', 'culture', & 'racism', including the development of guidelines. However, the operational problems of how to collect ethnicity data in studies of the sociology of health & illness have not been satisfactorily addressed. This paper explores conceptual issues, notably, the meanings of ethnic identity & ethnic origin/ancestry; methodological approaches, including which dimensions to collect, multidimensional vs global measures, & exclusive groups vs optional ethnicity; & also practical issues such as method of assignment. The approach calls for a stronger development of the theoretical understandings of ethnicity & work on how best ethnicity should be conceptualized & measured in the different approaches to explaining ethnic inequalities in health. 63 References. Adapted from the source document.", u'attribution': u'Sociological Abstracts'}, {u'abstract': u'\xa0 The writer examines the operational problems faced by investigators making necessary choices about how to collect ethnic group data in studies of the sociology of health and illness. He explores conceptual issues, including the meanings of ethnic identity and ethnic origin/ancestry; methodological approaches, including which dimensions to collect, multidimensional versus global measures, and exclusive groups versus optional ethnicity; and also practical issues such as method of assignment. He concludes by calling for stronger development of the theoretical understandings of ethnicity and more work on how to best conceptualize ethnicity.', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u'In response to the burgeoning interest in ethnic health issues and related published research, a number of recent contributors have attempted to clarify or systematise the usage of overarching terminology like \u2018ethnicity\u2019, \u2018race\u2019, \u2018culture\u2019, and \u2018racism\u2019, including the development of guidelines. However, the operational problems of how to collect ethnicity data in studies of the sociology of health and illness have not been satisfactorily addressed. This paper explores conceptual issues, notably, the meanings of ethnic identity and ethnic origin/ancestry; methodological approaches, including which dimensions to collect, multidimensional versus global measures, and exclusive groups versus optional ethnicity; and also practical issues such as method of assignment. The approach calls for a stronger development of the theoretical understandings of ethnicity and work on how best ethnicity should be conceptualised and measured in the different approaches to explaining ethnic inequalities in health.', u'attribution': u''}, {u'abstract': u"In response to the burgeoning interest in ethnic health issues and related published research, a number of recent contributors have attempted to clarify or systematise the usage of overarching terminology like 'ethnicity', 'race', 'culture', and 'racism', including the development of guidelines. However, the operational problems of how to collect ethnicity data in studies of the sociology of health and illness have not been satisfactorily addressed. This paper explores conceptual issues, notably, the meanings of ethnic identity and ethnic origin/ancestry; methodological approaches, including which dimensions to collect, multidimensional versus global measures, and exclusive groups versus optional ethnicity; and also practical issues such as method of assignment. The approach calls for a stronger development of the theoretical understandings of ethnicity and work on how best ethnicity should be conceptualised and measured in the different approaches to explaining ethnic inequalities in health.", u'attribution': u'Web of Science'}]}
